Videogame manuals are becoming a lost art. With the convenience of online distribution, developers have transitioned these former staples into digital formats, if the game even comes with one. Those who grew up playing the fifth generation of consoles understand that manuals are essential to enriching one’s experience. Many provide lore and backstory while teaching you how to play. In an age where they are a dying breed, Tunic takes the manual to the next level and incorporates it directly into the game, encouraging players to pay attention and use its clues to decipher puzzles. Ironic, considering that players control an illiterate fox. 

Tunic combines Legend of Zelda gameplay with Souls-like combat to create an exploration focused adventure. This is a game that absolutely refuses to hold your hand. Getting lost is common but don’t be discouraged. Unless you are attempting to 100%, most of the puzzles are reasonable. It’s only when you are attempting a completionist run that the game rears an ugly head. Some puzzles, including the one needed for the True End, are so obscure they border on perplexing. The manual also sorely lacks a way to bookmark pages for quick access. Rifling through just to return to the overworld map gets tedious fast. 

Despite these complaints, Tunic is a brilliant experience that comes off both nostalgic and fresh. It’s a meticulously crafted time capsule that’ll take you back to the days where you wrote down secret codes and inputs, where every discovery felt like uncovering ancient treasure the devs buried, and piecing together clues made you feel every bit as smart as those grown-ups.

I'll start off by saying that this is a good, greatly crafted game and you'll probably enjoy it. However, it's so, so much not for me, and I want to explore why.

Do you know the stories of when Kojima worked at Konami and that he was so weird with his gameplay ideas that there was always some dude watching over him and occasionally saying "Kojima, for the love of GOD, dial it down a notch"? I'm a game developer myself, experienced seeing such people as well. Tunic was made as if it never had such a dude at all.

I cannot comprehend who on earth would think that the first NES Zelda is a decent game. I also think this way about Dark Souls, but that's a more of a personal thing for me, as I know lots of people enjoy it. This game just smells of this idea "hey wouldn't it be cool if we crossed the first zelda with dark souls?". The whole manual-collecting thing is a cool concept, but it wants to play so hard into the mystery that the game has its own language to obfuscate info. But, oh gosh, QA figured out that this way nothing can be understood by some people, so some important text is still in English, making this obfuscation automatically artsy-fartsy pretentious.

Tons of the game also relies on unmarked secrets for progression, leading to getting stuck and being like doomguy hugging every wall in the original doom, only there it was for bonuses and was not vital. Some mechanics, although were explained in the manual (I think), could not be reliably executed, roll->attack for example, leading me to question if the game gaslights me with insufficient info, or if it's just a janky bugfest.

Oh, and the whole DS stuff. "Ha-ha, anything kills you in 1-2 hits, ha-ha!". I personally very much dislike this design and consider it cheap. It's not at all how zelda games play out, not even the latest, harder BOTW and TOTK. I could enable the relaxed difficulty in the accessibility settings, but I don't trust the game already! What'll it do behind my back with this option? Will it force me onto an automatic bad ending? Lock me out from it altogether? I'm paranoid already! The game made me paranoid!

The production of it is so, so great though, with genuinely great soundtrack, sound design and cleverly realized artistic rendering features. It's a joy experiencing it. For that reason alone I wanted to finish it, but the entire gimmick of it and the gameplay drive me nuts.

The developers clearly wanted to invite you and explore its every nook and cranny, and it has secrets in spades, even leading up to ARG content for the most dedicated ones, and that's great. However, in the end, at least for me, it doesn't become cryptic or mysterious, it becomes outright pretentiously hostile due to a portion of these secrets being obscenely mandatory and cryptic. I didn't enjoy solving them and battling against the mechanics of the game when I just wanted to move on. And that's unfortunate, because I can clearly see the passion behind it.

[h1]Aroma a clásico[/h1]
Si has disfrutado de los Zelda clásicos, ya te habrás dado cuenta de lo difícil que resulta imitarlos y que quede algo tan bueno como ellos. Es raro, porque como tal los Zelda clásicos no es que presenten nada que a priori sea difícil de copiar, pero no será tan fácil de hacer cuando tantos lo intentan y casi ninguno lo consigue.

Tunic bebe mucho de los Zeldas originales, especialmente del primero de NES y de “A Link to the Past”, y aunque no es un Zelda como tal, ya que ni siquiera hay poblados ni interacción alguna con otros personajes digna de mención, sí que se siente esa vibra tan magnífica que tiene esa gran saga. Esto tiene sus matices, pero digamos que consigue en buena medida presentar una aventura con un aire totalmente clásico, realmente entretenido y muy desafiante en algunos momentos.

[h1]Cripticismo por bandera[/h1]
Si hay algo que vas a experimentar constantemente en Tunic es no saber qué está pasando, sobre todo al principio. Esto puede desanimar a algunos, ya que no a todo el mundo le gusta lanzarse a la aventura sin tener al menos un sostén argumentativo al que agarrarse, pero Tunic es así. De todos modos, lo mejor es marchar hacia adelante y ya veremos qué va pasando mientras avanzamos.

Esto no quiere decir que nos vayamos a perder y no saber qué hacer en absoluto. El juego está muy bien planteado para que no podamos acceder a determinados sitios si no poseemos un arma, un objeto o una habilidad en particular, así que la sensación de estar perdidos existe, pero nunca lo estaremos de tal modo que no encontremos cómo progresar en la aventura.

El juego es críptico desde el primer momento hasta bien llegada su parte final, pero mientras más vayamos avanzando mejor iremos comprendiendo ese mundo, aunque use un lenguaje inventado que no podemos descifrar salvo por palabras sueltas escritas en español.

Ya de hecho nada más comenzar lo haremos tirados en una playa, y sin arma o protección alguna. Pero nada temas, pues nuestro zorrete tendrá su primera arma en una casa muy cerca de donde está: un magnífico palo de madera. No es que nos quedara muy claro lo que indicaba el cartel que leímos antes de entrar en esa casa, ya que, como he dicho, el idioma es inventado. Pero es un palo, y seguro que todo el mundo sabe cómo usarlo, incluido nuestro zorrete.

Más adelante, encontraremos una página suelta tirada en el suelo, y al leerla veremos que hemos encontrado el mejor tesoro que posee este juego: el manual.

[h1]¡Mi reino por un manual completo![/h1]
Sin duda, es extraordinariamente original meter dentro de un juego el manual del mismo juego desperdigando sus páginas por los diferentes lugares que visitaremos. Es una manera brutal de romper la cuarta pared, ya que cuando lo consultamos, lo cual haremos bastante a menudo una vez conseguidas las páginas de los mapas y mazmorras, el juego hará un efecto de zum alejado de tal modo que la pantalla del juego se convertirá en una televisión de las antiguas de tubo, con el manual en primer plano. 

De todos modos, no hay que emocionarse en exceso, porque el manual es casi tan críptico como los carteles o las pocas “conversaciones” que podamos ver dentro del juego. La diferencia es que tendrá palabras sueltas en español aquí y allá, y así se podrá deducir qué es o qué hace tal o cual objeto, o por dónde tenemos que tirar en esa mazmorra que nos tiene un tanto perdidos.

Yo no había visto una cosa igual llevada a tal extremo, y solo puedo definirlo como una auténtica genialidad. Al final, querrás ir recogiendo más y más hojas, para enterarte de más cosas sobre el argumento central del juego y qué está haciendo el zorrete, qué pasa en ese mundo y cuál es nuestro papel en él. En este aspecto, no encontrarás nada ni remotamente parecido en otro juego. Sublime podría ser una palabra bastante acertada para definirlo.

[h1]Combate, exploración y mazmorras[/h1]
Dicho esto, el juego no se basa en ir recogiendo hojas de un manual, eso es un añadido fundamental, pero no su núcleo jugable. El juego es básicamente un Zelda clásico en su vertiente de acción, donde tendremos que explorar el entorno, visitar diferentes biomas, entrar en mazmorras e ir descubriendo poco a poco sus secretos mientras nos hacemos con nuevas armas, objetos y habilidades.

El combate es bastante básico, basado principalmente en el ataque, la esquiva y el uso del escudo una vez obtenido, pero funciona de maravilla. Es tremendamente dinámico y muy entretenido. En mi opinión no es nada difícil, sino que su dificultad es perfecta para ser un reto, pero sin llegar a frustrar. Ya sabes, de esos combates tipo: “Me han dejado el ojal como un bebedero de patos, pero sé que puedo pasarlo si me concentro”. Bueno, esto solo pasará con algunos jefes finales realmente, y el último combate sí puede llegar a ser bastante frustrante, pero nada imposible tampoco. 

En sí, el combate cumple a la perfección, pero no es el punto donde reside su dificultad. Su dificultad reside más en la resolución de puzles, y más aún si quieres descubrirlo todo.

[h1]Puzles que te harán pensar[/h1]
No es que los puzles en general sean una locura en su dificultad, pero sí que te obligan a fijarte en el entorno. Básicamente, casi todos los puzles se basan en tirar de palancas, presionar placas para abrir nuevos caminos, utilizar determinados objetos y ese tipo de cosas. De hecho, no dista mucho de lo que puede verse en “A Link to the Past”, pero algunos tienen un añadido realmente sorprendente: tu propio mando.

Antiguamente, era común meter combinaciones de pulsaciones en un juego para obtener algún tipo de beneficio como desbloquear personajes, más vida y ese tipo de cosas. Era una especie de truco que generalmente se utilizaba en el menú principal y conllevaba pulsar diferentes patrones de arriba, abajo, izquierda dos veces y este tipo de cosas. Tunic hace uso de eso, pero directamente aplicado en el juego, y te “chiva” lo que tienes que hacer bien sea en un muro de piedra o directamente en el manual con anotaciones hechas con boli. Tremendamente original esto último.

Por ejemplo, si estamos delante de una puerta o una pared y vemos un patrón, igual te da por presionar el pad en esas direcciones que se indica en el dibujo y suena una musiquilla indicando que eres tope listo, y te sientes genial. A mí me pasó, y he de admitir que me pareció increíble que funcionara. Lo hice por hacerlo, por hacer la tontería, pero no lo era en absoluto, sino justamente lo que tenía que hacer.

De todos modos, tienes que tener claro que este tipo de puzles de pulsaciones solo son en su mayoría para conseguirlo todo, y no se abusa demasiado de esto para terminar la aventura y se suele indicar en el manual “claramente” lo que hay que hacer en esos casos, así que no desesperes.

Aunque es cierto que a los desarrolladores se les fue la mano con algunos coleccionables, y es verdad que las instrucciones están en el manual, pero deducirlo hasta ese nivel en algunas ocasiones ya es un tanto “porque patata”. De todos modos, esto último no es necesario para acabar el juego como he dicho.

[h1]Conclusiones[/h1]
Cada cierto tiempo sale al mercado un juego que es pura originalidad se mire por donde se mire. Tunic es uno de esos juegos. Tiene la virtud de ofrecer un planteamiento clásico y además llegar en su planteamiento jugable a donde ningún otro juego ha llegado. Es toda una joya y una oda a la imaginación más desbordante y sorprendente.

[h3]WARNING:[/h3] This game has 2 very different aspects to it: A beautiful and enthralling puzzle game, and an atrocious and overly punishing action rpg. 
I very much want to recommend the puzzle game but in order to enjoy it you need to endure the combat, so take this into account before buying.

Combat is extremely basic and janky, with no input buffering, no animation cancelling, terrible hitbox size and timing, and the cheesiest AI possible.
To make it all worse, the dev decided for some reason to also make it VERY unforgiving, which means fights turn into a central part of the game where you will spend a long (bad) time.

The puzzle part is a very clear homage to Fez, but does enough to stand on its own. The game gives the information in very clever ways for you to piece together the solution to the world's mysteries. 
It has perspective puzzles, some cool eureka moments, a full cypher language to translate (optional) and more. Unlike the combat part, it's clear that the devs knew what they were doing. It's very well crafted to great detail. My only gripe is that it relies too much on perspective gimmicks, which forces you to try to constantly wiggle your character in obscured areas in search for secret doors. 

In summary very hard for me to rate this game since it has a half that I love and a half that I hate. The whole also suffers because of the stylistic clash of the chill/mellow mystery solving and the harsh/unpolished/hostile action segments.  
      
If you love puzzle games and can tolerate some (a lot) of senseless souls-esque BS, give it a try on sale.

As a preface to this review, I want to say that I think this game is absolutely amazing and 100% worth a blind playthrough by anyone remotely interested in the genre. That being said, I'm using this review to vent my autistic nitpicks with certain aspects of the game. Despite everything I'm about to say, the game is still a 9 or 10 out of 10 for all the reasons stated in other reviews.

[spoiler]
The worst part about the combat system in this game is the incredibly short iframe window on the dodgeroll, and how long it takes to execute. This really comes apparent once you reach the final portion of the game and unlock the teleportation crown. The final boss is significantly more fun than every other boss that came before it purely because there is more engaging gameplay that can be done around the improved dash. I unironically believe that if the dash had been that way from the start (obviously minus the ability to teleport across gaps) and the game was balanced accordingly, the combat as a whole would be much more fun. The distance could even be shortened until the crown is acquired later.

Consumables in this game outside the blastbomb and the fire bomb are completely useless. The frost bomb is a neat idea but is completely overshadowed by a magic item that does the exact same thing you will acquire very early in the game. The ivy and hot pepper both do not provide noticeable enough stat increases to warrant consistent usage. At most, you may use them a few times before a boss, but ultimately they really don't have much of an effect. The lure, as far as I can tell, is only useful for speedruns or specific challenge runs and had basically no application in my first playthrough. The fruits are only helpful in very select circumstances when your flask charges are completely empty AND you aren't in combat. Which brings me to the main problem with the consumable system: the hotbar. Only three items can be equipped to it, and many of them are not worth a slot that could otherwise be devoted to a precious magic item. I'm not sure how exactly the developers could've addressed this--my only thought would be a system similar to Dark Souls with a slot in the hotbar that can be cycled between consumables.

Continuing the hotbar discussion, it's unfortunate that for much of your exploration one of your hotbar slots must always be relegated to the magic orb for grapples. I think it might have been best to allow you to grapple over to a hook with a certain button whenever focusing on that hook.

For the most part, the endgame puzzle solving in this game is absolutely genius and incredibly fun to play through. That being said, I have a few nitpicks of a few puzzles that felt flatly unfair. My beliefs in these criticisms are not nearly as substantial as the previously mentioned ones, and it's entirely possible that I'm missing something with the puzzles. If so, please correct me.

-Fairy 8 requires the player to go to a certain location in the Eastern Forest at nighttime and follow the movements of a phantom fox to solve the puzzle. The issue is that there is absolutely no indication you should visit here at night. In fact, the area is seemingly completely blocked off during nighttime and can only be reached through a secret path up to the fox. I would be fine with this if there was any clue at all that hinted at returning at night, but as far as I can tell there is absolutely none.

The Eastern Fortress is one of my favorite areas in the game in terms of design, but unfortunately my experience with it and its boss was weighed down because I began it after already completing the quarry and ruined atoll. I'm not sure if this is true of whichever of these three zones you tackle last, but I steamrolled through most of the enemies with little difficulty which was a bit of an underwhelming way to end the second act of the game. 

-Fairy 15: Much like the previous fairy, the issue with this one is not the puzzle itself but rather the means of accessing it. To reach the puzzle, you must use a bomb to blow a hole in the wall the fairies lead you to. Again, however, there is no indication that this would make sense to do, and (at least as far as I can tell) you never blow up a wall at any other point in the game.

-Fairy 20: I adore this fairy conceptually, but again, the issue is actually gathering together the pieces of the puzzle. The game relies on you either having an incredible memory and returning to all the locations with golden obelisk fragments OR you being willing to run throughout the entire map trying to find every last piece of the obelisk. This would be acceptable if there was some indication on the map of where golden obelisk fragments are, but only some are actually given this.

-Golden Path Page 8: My only issue here is that the first time I exited to the pause screen, the secret save was not there. I assume this is a bug, but it's something I've seen talked about online as well and would expect to be fixed a year after release.
[/spoiler]

As I mentioned at the start, this game is a must-play for basically anyone. I just wanted to share my few nitpicks with some aspects of the game.

146818750.review:
Fantastic game, something I haven't ever really seen tried before, and it succeeds on all accounts.

The design of the earliest console games (NES, yes I know there's older) is basically alien to the modern gaming ecosystem and doesn't really exist anymore. Remakes and rereleases of old games which clean up the gameplay make it less and less likely for people to be remotely familiar with the oldest tropes, but Tunic sets out to remedy that. This game recreates the experience of playing a game in a language you don't really know and whose mechanics are never explained in-game anyway, with nothing but guess-and-check to guide you through and relying on others to fill in the gaps. It's impossible to replicate exactly, of course; many of the most distinct aspects of these early games (secrets scattered around a map haphazardly, dumbass useless NPCs, legitimately inscrutable gameplay mechanics) were due to time constraints or incompetence or both. Here, since they all have intention behind them, they're much gentler; secrets are hard, but deliberate, and there's no major quality of life issues with the gameplay. The NPCs are hilariously useless (and don't type in English), but if you translate them a few of them are actually useful and don't just sit around saying "GO TO THE NEXT ROOM" or whatever. The combat is probably the furthest away from older design out of anything in the game, and feels mostly modern though I think it works very well. 

The game shines in its design philosophy; the vast majority of progress in the game rewards you with knowledge, and not tangible checkpoints. When you reach a new area, you find out that there was a ladder to the beginning all along; when you pass a crucial point you find out how to use overworld objects that were available and functional for the entire game. It's not items, but knowledge, that shapes your journey, and if you have the knowledge from the get-go you can travel all over the place in any order you like for the most part.

Gamers of yesteryear were quite fond of speculating about esoteric sequences of button-presses and their real or imagined impact on gameplay. It's obviously been quite popular to actually put these obscure secrets into games for more than a decade now (after all, most game devs grew up when it was popular). Tunic follows a similar philosophy, and while the idea behind the holy cross puzzles isn't new it's very well-executed, much better than most other games that attempt it. Very few of the puzzles are overly obscure and even then the game gives you ample hints.

It's interesting looking at reviews for this, since it seems like the intent of the game flew right over most players' heads at mach five. You know the industry is just straight up fucked when the only frame of reference most players have is Dark Souls, but I guess the likelihood of most modern players having touched any of the games this is based off of is pretty low. I'm honestly not even sure most players of this game have played Fez, which goes a long way to explain the general attitude towards it. It's a shame, but for the game's intended audience, it doesn't get much better than this. 8/10

I didn't expect to enjoy this game. I'm not a fan of isometric games, nor do I like the general artstyle of the game. On top of that, I've currently got a bit of Soulslike fatigue. So, I didn't expect to enjoy a game that looks like a mesh together of Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls. Time and time again Tunic would be recommended by someone I respect. I'd consider it, then decide against it. But something about the overwhelmingly positive reviews eventually swayed me to get it. 

And I don't regret my decision one bit.

[b]Exploration[/b]
The exploration in this game is fantastic. The game is in part a metroidvania - with traversal abilities you can unlock that allow you to explore the world. The game is also "metroidbrainia", with abilities you can do from the start, you just don't know how. The world is nicely interconnected with many satisfying shortcuts you can unlock along the way.

[b]The Manual[/b]
The game drip feeds you pages of a manual, but unlike pretty much every manual in existence, this one doesn't bore me to death. In fact, it's fantastic! Most of it is encoded in a strange different language, with only key bits of information in English or told via images. The game slowly lets you in on little tips and tricks, but you don't NEED the manual, you can figure these abilities out on your own (and when that happens it is very satisfying).

[b]Visuals[/b]
I mentioned earlier that the artstyle was not my favourite. Despite this, the animations, colour scheme, and the sound design are masterfully put together. The environments are far more varied than I would have expected. While I loved the atmosphere of the rustic forest temple-y areas, there were more impressive areas later into the game.

[b]Progression[/b]
The progression in abilities feels great. I love it when games make loot that feels valuable and most loot either contributes directly to a valuable upgrade, gives you an upgrade, or rewards you with information. 

[b]Combat[/b]
The combat was good. The final boss was fantastic. The bosses in the runup ranged from decent to great. I had a little trouble with the lock-on system, but all of this could have been mitigated if I'd used the arrow keys to switch lock on targets. Even despite my Soulslike fatigue I still enjoyed the combat. 

[b]Puzzles[/b]
You don't need to solve any [i]real[/i] puzzles to get an ending, but if you want to get the [i]good[/i] ending there are a lot to solve. The final puzzle required for the good ending is incredible. There are hints hidden right under your nose throughout the game; when you figure out the solution, it feels absolutely amazing. One downside, however, is when executing the puzzle solution, it is very easy to make a tiny error interpreting parts of it - which then unfolds into an unfortunately frustrating experience diagnosing the small error you made. At the end of the day though, I am still very satisfied with my experience figuring it out. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
This game had me hooked. From ringing the bells to now (having just completed the good ending) I had a burning desire to uncover the secrets around every corner; it takes masterful game design to create that feeling. I was able to recapture similar feelings in this game as when solving puzzles in Outer Wilds. I highly recommend playing this, and I highly recommend playing it blind.

So the first 5-7 hours or so were fantastic for sure. Atmosphere is great, combat is not bad ("not bad" being the best it'll ever get ) and you figure out game mechanics through clever use of finding manual pages and part of the game is puzzling out how things work. All of this, when it works comes together well and feels great.
However when it fails it fails also really hard and all the fun goes out the window pretty fast. There's multiple ways the game can do that. 
One is to simply be stuck on not figuring out where to go. Thankfully this didn't happen a lot to me and usually I could find my way to looking over the "map" again and deciding that "there is probably something here, so let's check that section out again". But generally almost all access points are hidden by the perspective of the camera. Be that hidden ladders or corridors or whatnot. I get the throwback to older games where some secrets where hidden that way, but it's way, wayyy overdone here by being basically the default way of going from section to section at times. This also makes it more annoying to remember which way you needed to go when going through an area later.
Another really bad aspect is the combat. At first it's not too bad, since both you and the enemies seem equally clunky. But in the second half of the game enemies are mostly a keep away AI that runs away from you and then attacks from long range. And for some enemies it takes you longer to swing and hit with your weapon after they just attacked you than it takes the enemies to run away from you again. Some also get invulnerability frames just after their attack so you're guaranteed not able to hit them. Basically, most basic enemies become a huge pain in the ass while adding nothing interesting to combat.
Similar for bosses. except bosses have the extra problem that for some the camera moves too fast (as it's always on the boss) so aside from that one boss where during a specific sequence all it does is circle around you (and thus move the camera, which made me dizzy as heck after a while) you often get problems of the boss attacking while moving fast that leads to not quite seeing what's going on or inputs not working, or blocking not working cause your character turns too fast (or not fast enough, idk). which means sometimes you block sometimes you don't which is also quite frustrating. Aside from the same keep away/i-frame stuff on top, which just drags out the already not so fun battles too much.
Then the secret puzzles. I'd say I can see how some people can get really into those. And good for you, I hope you had a lot of fun with hose, but unless you enjoy staring at cryptic messages and just trying stuff out a lot and never getting clear feedback it's seems a bit too much trial and error. I even had it happened that I actually correctly figured out what to do, but then it didn't work anyway, so I assumed I needed maybe a certain item first, but as it turns out I did everything correctly already, it just didn't work as intended (for whatever reason), so that kinda sucked big time. 
Some puzzles/clues are incredibly vague at times and some seemingly require you to translate that whole fake language to even get the clues. So if you enjoy that kinda stuff, that's probably a plus, but I just thought the game had its head up wayy too far it's own arse at that point tbh.

146430839.review:
I played this after Tears of the Kingdom, several 2D Zelda games, and Sable (clearly BotW-inspired but chill) because I was still in the mood for something else vaguely Zelda-like.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
-Based on the preview images, I came into this game expecting an isometric puzzle platformer rather than a strict homage to Zelda and was not disappointed. I really hope more developers bring this isometric style back now that we all have full analog controllers, which was the main hurdle in the 8- and 16-bit console eras. There's a certain satisfaction from making all parts of an area slowly click into place.
-The art styles, both in the main game world and the NES Zelda-style in-game booklet, are wonderful. I'd sometimes stop walking around just to take in the airbrushed geometric art of the game world.
-The regular sword/shield/etc. item mechanics are straightforward and give you a lot of freedom in how you map them.
-The orb/whip is super fun once you get that. You can get into some hilarity by whip-snapping enemies over to you.
-Difficulty toggles.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-The shadows in dark areas are a bit hard to see subtle details in even after bumping the brightness.
-It worked with a PS5 controller, my preferred Steam controller, but kept showing XBox button names. The choices for how the menu controls were mapped were also strange.
-Targeting is a bit dodgy. You need it not just for attacks, but snapping yourself around using the orb.
-After the first bell, the difficulty ramped up ridiculously. I toggled invincibility on after getting repeatedly brutalized by the crocodile enemies and could tell I would not have passed the quarry or ziggurat. It has its own equivalent to the Gloom from Tears of the Kingdom, but more frustrating.
-The Souls-like leveling mechanic doesn't intuitively fit in with the retro aesthetic. I had the manual page for it but it didn't click what it was telling me to do until I looked up a guide online.
-Several other mechanics, like teleporting, don't have any subtle UI cues beyond anything shown in the manual.
-There's too many collectibles and they're not fun like the regular platform puzzles. After a point, I pulled up a guide and powered through them to get the Steam achievements rather than for their own sake. I wouldn't have bothered getting them at all if I'd bought this game for the Switch instead. The gold skulls one was my least favorite because the physics were wonky.
-The devs are way too in love with the Wind Fish Egg puzzle from Link's Awakening. It's repeatedly rehashed here, such as for a good chunk of the hidden collectibles, but in longer and even more annoying ways. 
-I still didn't entirely get what was going on plot-wise even after collecting the whole manual.

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]
-I was back and forth on how I felt about the gimmick of the fake foreign language in the in-game UI and the manual pages. It's a novel idea, but it sometimes got in the way of getting my head wrapped around the game mechanics. I think I would have preferred something where the fake language translates itself bit-by-bit as you collect more pages, with 100% manual pages = 100% translated.

TLDR; fun premise and artwork let down by a quasi-attempt to make it a Souls-like and the devs forgetting that some 8-bit era game mechanics were just cheap rather than a fun challenge.

Tunic is a cute game that initially appears as a standard rpg where you go around the world finding treasure, getting stronger, and killing bosses. The art style is simple yet experssive and the music is soft and atmospheric. While the combat targetting can be finicky against multiple enemies, it works.
What sets the game apart is how you learn mechanics and get hints: by literally collecting pages of the game's manual.
Even if you don't care for the hidden secrets, Tunic still has the basic outline of a story through the manual pages you do collect and even provides a twist, all without any dialog and with most text in a made up runic language. However, going for all the collectables is where the game really shines.
Poring through the manual and understanding certain parts of it literally changes how you view the environment and the world's design. The isometric view and world design is cleverly used to hide secrets; you will miss something the first time around, no matter how thorough you think you were. Rereading manual pages to realize how to get to something you missed or understanding the initially random scribbles within the manual itself is very satisfying. However, not understanding or missing something can lead to you wandering around for a long time not knowing what to do. This is something that applies to the game whether you are going for 100% completion or not, but is a lot more noticeable while searching for every last secret.

Tunic is a game best experienced as blind as you can. Only look up hints or guides as a last resort. The only exceptions I'd say are worth it are the two achievements that will be missed during a vanilla blind playthrough as it requires having the pages for two specific items, translating their descriptions, and inferring the meaning. By the time you have the resources to do so, you will have most likely already failed the conditions to get them. In addition, the items in particular don't really have a reason to be explicitly translated as you've probably inferred the descriptions while using them, meaning you'll be going out of your way to translate them.

I have many fond memories as a kid playing Zelda: Oracle of Seasons, Oracle of Ages, and Link's Awakening on my Gameboy Color. After starting Tunic these memories immediately came flooding back.

Tunic takes the Zelda formula and not only executes it, but improves upon it. Combat and movement are clean and crisp. The music and atmosphere were two of my favorite aspects of Tunic. The artistic design is breathtaking. I especially loved the in game guidebook idea. There was absolutely no handholding for Tunic: you were given all the information that you need to solve the games many puzzles. This is something that many games today are lacking.

That said, towards the end of my playthrough I came to the bitter realization that I lack the patience I once had as a kid. Technically everything you need to know is explained in the guidebook, but some of the more nuanced details can be difficult to figure out. Without spoiling anything, I got stuck trying to find a specific key item, which completely halted my game progression for some time. Because I couldn't figure it out using the guidebook, I looked it up online. This was a big mistake, as doing so immediately killed my immersion within the game. The entire point of the guidebook is to find things out yourself, which prior to this point provided a great feeling of accomplishment figuring things out on my own. While this was mostly my own fault, I would argue that the description of how to get said item (or even the existence of said item) was not entirely clear from the guidebook. General ordering/progression could have been made more clear.

Overall I would give Tunic a high rating, but it is far from perfect. With some minor improvements Tunic has the opportunity to be a truly incredible game. I sincerely hope they decide to make a sequel!

Although calling "Tunic" an in-depth metroidvania from an isometric perspective is correct, it doesn't properly convey what an adventure this game was.
More than just beating bosses to unlock gameplay mechanics, "Tunic" also unlocks gameplay mechanics by awarding players with pages of a manual — one that's written almost entirely in a fictitious language accompanied by colourful symbols and illustrations. It is then up to you, the player, to give your best guess in interpreting the pages because these pages hold the secrets to abilities you've had ever since the beginning — you simply hadn't known yet.

In a literal sense, knowledge is power.
More than collecting items that add abilities to your arsenal, more than testing your technical skill with the controls, "Tunic" is a game where your curiosity in exploration and intuition in cryptic data are rewarded with power. More so than most metroidvanias, knowledge makes you more powerful.
That feeling of acquiring knowledge gives a potent shot of exhilaration surpassed only by another knowledge-based game I've played — The Outer Wilds.

I strongly recommend playing Tunic.

143494910.review:
Tunic is an ingenious mesh of well-proven inspirations and new ideas. The game is often as much of a tricky puzzle game as it is an enjoyable and familiar-looking action RPG. Tunic undeniably lifts the base of its presentation, top-down camera, tough-yet-fair sword-and-shield combat, and clever interconnected level design from iconic sources (i.e. Link's Awakening and Dark Souls), but the game adds a layer of ‘knowledge-progression’ that’s hidden within a nostalgic, half-translated in-game strategy guide.

In a gripping perspective-expanding process akin to the joy of solving Outer Wilds, from the start, you essentially already have everything you need to go anywhere (or at least do some serious sequence breaking before key items get in the way), but you don’t yet know enough about this new land to harness your own potential. Here, knowledge from the game’s scattered manual has the same door-opening/problem-solving power as keys or ‘super missiles’ might. While you go about the intended adventuring route, so many shortcuts and interactions lay just out of reach, merely hiding in plain sight.

The value Tunic places on information is quite refreshing. As your tools and stats progress, so does your understanding of the world. You have no idea what subtle details could become relevant later, which bestows this unknown depth and mystery to the whole experience. When new pages of lovely art and inconclusive imagery are revealed to you, deciphering them makes you feel like a real detective. I also love the dramatic irony of knowing that nothing was stopping you from your goals besides a trick that seemed obvious in retrospect.

This [i]retro-and-other-inspired RPG that incorporates its manual into the pacing of its gameplay[/i] concept works so well. That guidebook/exploration dynamic makes for some unforgettable moments. But it’s also worth briefly complimenting how Tunic’s other components elevate the game into something much greater than the sum of its sources. The story is told indirectly and silently. It brings further intrigue into this seemingly friendly animal world. The music, while an initially unexpected tone, evokes waves of synthy nostalgia. Tunic’s soundtrack could’ve been a lot more predictable and I think Lifeformed and Janice Kwan found a great way to add to Tunic’s unique identity. Combat isn’t a major thrill, but it has good moment-to-moment pacing. While parrying is a little slugging, it’s far from necessary to succeed. Most bosses require ample mastery to overcome without having to pull out any hairs.

And if it ended there, I wouldn’t be hesitant to rank Tunic among its like-minded masterpieces.

Sadly, the game ends on a pretty painful note. [spoiler]It begins with a slew of backtracking. Some paths are new, a lot are now blocked. Some upgrade materials you missed are also blocked off. Combat essentially doesn't exist for this portion. There’s nothing in your way as you run around, looking for the clues from the manual. For the final set of new adventuring material, Tunic asks you to take an extreme dive into the manual for cryptic secrets which demand a lot of brainpower and offer no tactile reward. And, as you’d expect, the final boss isn't anything trivial. [/spoiler]

I was so into the first two-thirds of this game. Tunic is still certainly worth experiencing for those first ten-ish hours, so don't let my need to discuss my discontent with the final act stain your impressions of the truly brilliant parts. Seeing as fun as Tunic’s learning process was, perhaps it’s fitting that an end to that growth would entail a decline in my interest in it.

It's really frustrating seeing more bad reviews than I would have expected, as this is now easily one of my top 5 indie games of all time. The bad reviews seem to come from either the heavy puzzle aspect or heavy combat portion of the game.

Puzzle-wise, this game completely blew my mind in the best way possible. Nothing in the game is put by accident. There's layers upon layers of puzzles in this game. And it's really up to you how much to invest on them. One definitely has to do part of the puzzles to advance the game's main story. But the more obscure ones are completely optional. The amount I discovered on my own left me very satisfied by how well designed they are. And I looked up the rest just to have a better sense of how deep the puzzling gets. I will say here that  in order to enjoy the game, you do need to really enjoy puzzles (as there's no direct accessibility option to completely eliminate that). And some puzzles might take multiple tries.

Combat-wise, it is definitely a tough game. However, although it was my first souls-like game, my skills got better the more I advanced in the game. To the degree that when I did one of the bosses out of order, I was able to kill a previous boss on my first try. However, there was a section where I think it got significantly harder in compared to other sections (which I found more challenging than the final boss). Because here, your upgrades didn't matter as much, and it was all about skill and weapons/items. It was also particularly harder for me as I missed a weapon that would have made it easier. Regardless, I was able to beat it after a very stressful try. And if I would have been really stuck, I could have just used the accessibility options!

It's also worth mentioning how amazing the artstyle is. The cute vibe is all I ever needed, we really need more cute yet challenging games. But also, the aesthetics and texture of everything is so good. And the manual is wonderful, of course.

Last, but not least, the music and sound effects are incredible as well. They both effectively make the game significantly better. From the very beginning of the game, to the jumpscare of finding a boss, and everything in between.

I think it would be useful to talk about each of these components in depth.

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
This part is about the exploration. If you’ve done a good enough job to avoid any spoilers, then upon starting the game everything is very mysterious and you’re basically just doing the only things that you’re able to. You don’t have a lot of options about where you want to go or what you want to do, but that’s okay because you’re still figuring out how the game works. Over time, the area that you can explore and the speed at which you can do so improve by exploring, fighting, and solving puzzles. The world is just big enough to feel daunting and exciting, but not too big that it’s tedious to explore.

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]
Now about the puzzles, which are my favorite part. As soon as you start the game, you're constantly finding weird new pieces to puzzles that you're unsure how they work / didn't know existed. Often, you'll slowly piece together how some of the puzzle’s rules might work until you find the solution to how they function in the manual. Not all the puzzles are solved in the same way, so you're constantly finding new information. There's different types of puzzles that all have unique rules. In function it works like this: 

There's a new type of puzzle that is present in the world obstructing your progress. Over time you'll find pieces of information in the manual, but not enough to figure out how to solve the puzzle type in entirety. You can guess the general gist, but enough to actually solve anything yet. Then suddenly after a big fight or cool new area you find a manual piece that reveals exactly how the puzzle works! Now you must remember where you found those individual puzzles so that you can attempt to solve them. Each of the individual puzzles will have a cool twist that make them still fun to solve even after understanding how the rules work.

There’s also a [b]LOT[/b] to work on with the puzzles. The number of secrets in this game is unbelievable, they’re basically everywhere. There’s also categories of puzzles that range from easy to communal, and necessary to not even in the game. You can just solve the easy ones to beat the game if you’d like or take on the harder ones although they’re not necessary. I recommend that you try to solve as many secrets and puzzles as you can and then just look up the rest. Eventually the difficulty of the puzzles increases beyond the scope of what a single person can achieve.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Puzzles aren't the only way you make progress, however. Sometimes there's just an elaborate dungeon that you must explore and get to the end for a new weapon or tool. The combat has always taken a backseat to the puzzles in my opinion, but it's never boring. Enemies are basically just an obstacle. Fortunately, they're simple enough to deal with that I didn't mind fighting them, but the strategy was deep enough that I wasn't bored. It's exactly the kind of combat you want from a game that isn't solely focused on combat. You can attack, roll, and block along with some other items and consumables to mix things up. It’s more about your opponent’s attack patterns that makes the combat enjoyable.

[h1]Possible Downsides[/h1]
However, there are some things that you should know if you’re considering buying this game. I feel there are two main things that will turn a lot of people away and it’s best that you know beforehand. Exploring an isometric world might be annoying and this game really isn’t about the combat.

A lot of emphasis has been put on exploring an isometric world, which includes rubbing your face on areas that are obstructed by the players perspective. Often, there are optional treasure chests that are hidden behind your perspective, but sometimes it’s a really important area that is easy to miss. It’s the game’s job to try to communicate to the player that there could be something hiding out of view, and it usually does a good enough job. It’s simply another type of puzzle - trying to find hidden areas. I thought it was a lot of fun, but I can easily see how this would be a turn off to some. If this sounds frustrating, then this game may not be for you.

If you’re a fan of action type games and you’re looking to buy this because it has the tag ‘Souls-like’, that’s kind of deceptive. This game has light combat elements. There are only a handful of challenging fights in the game but they’re simple once you figure out their attack patterns. It’s difficult enough to be fun, but it’s not really the focus of the game. If you like combat more than puzzles in games, just be cautious about playing past two hours for the refund.

142740249.review:
TL:DR - It's a fun combo of Zelda & Dark Souls. If you like that, I recommend it. If you played video games in the 90's, I REALLY recommend it.

I'm not entirely sure how to rate this game, because the thing I love about it most is something that might only appeal to old people like me. 

At face value, it's a pretty neat Zelda/Dark Souls mash-up of a game. It has some key components of each, although it's not quite as good as either at doing the things those games do well. The thing that really makes me love it is the powerful sense of nostalgia I get from the in-game manual mechanic.

When I was a kid, the Internet wasn't widely used. There are a lot of ways that made everyday life different, but the one that's relevant to this game is that if you were a kid that played video games, it was pretty difficult to look up guides or secrets. If you got stuck, you just kept playing and banging your head against a wall until you figured something out. I have vivid memories of sleepovers with friends doing this with Zelda 2, Star Tropics, Zelda, a Link to the Past, and Super Metroid - we would get to a point where we were stuck, and all we could do was stay up all night re-exploring areas we'd been to, trying our different weapons on weird looking walls, and consulting the instruction manual for any tips we could hope to use to progress. 

This game is excellent at conjuring that same feeling. Instead of having a physical copy of the manual, you locate the pages of it in game as you play. The art in the manual brought back strong flashbacks to old NES and SNES manuals - if you zoom in you can see the dots from the print, there are things written in the manual in pencil, and you can even see the game being played  behind it, adjusted to look like it's on an old CRT screen. There are a lot of moments where I got stuck in the game, went to the manual, dug through it, and figured out what to do next. It was an exciting feeling that I had forgotten about - most current games make your objectives clear, and if you're stumped, there's a website ready to tell you what to do next. Playing this game cold with nothing but the in-game instruction booklet really took me back to the basement of a friends house at 2 AM, trying to figure out what came next. 

So here's the thing - I really enjoyed that experience, but I'm not entirely sure if that would be an enjoyable experience for someone who it didn't trigger the nostalgia that I felt. If you don't like that experience, it's a pretty cute Zelda/Dark Souls hybrid - not quite as good as either, but it's neat to see the two combined.

142511803.review:
This game feels so tailor-made for me so I just have to write a gushing review for it! It's a combination of incredibly smart game design which relies on minimal hand-holding and rewards your curiosity; puzzles that give you that 'AHA!' moment and unlock a whole new way of looking at the world once they click; isometric action combat that feels just challenging enough to keep you on your toes but never making you feel like the task is impossible and you aren't going to progress further; beautiful art direction and compelling world-building through visual storytelling and last but not least, a cute af protagonist. If you are like me and all of that sounds exactly up your alley, then I highly recommend TUNIC! 

Very quickly into the game, TUNIC teaches you to be observant. You will not be able to progress unless you are curious and are looking for visual clues at all times. The most unique mechanic that TUNIC has is a game manual which can be accessed at any time and contains everything you will need to beat the game and solve even its hardest puzzles. It's very much inspired by actual retro game manuals and the aesthetic of it is *chef's kiss*. The twist is that the manual pages are written in a foreign language with only some english sprinkled around to guide you. You are also able to find only certain pages at a time so you are forced to solve as much as possible with as little as you have. You aren't always sure if you already have the information to engage with what you're finding so that fuels your curiosity even more.

[b] How much CAN i do with what little I know? [/b] 

One of the smartest parts of TUNIC's design is how both your discoveries in the world and your reading of the manual pages is teaching you to be observant. You will always be rewarded for using your eyes in this game. As you progress the game will also reveal hidden paths & ladders that have been there all along, you just didn't know it but you [i] could've[/i] seen had you been looking closer. You will find little scribbles on maps in the manual, only to discover secret chests/paths/etc. in the world. It's an extremely smart loop of both secrets in the manual and smart level design that just constantly fuels your sense of wonder, curiosity and gives you a dopamine rush every time you figure out any of its secrets. I never found myself stuck or lost simply by keeping an eye out.

Fair bit of advice though, go in as blind as possible (don't even watch the trailer/video on steam as it gives a fair bit away that would otherwise feel more rewarding to discover on your own). I went in knowing very little about the game except that it was a game all about discovery, had a cool retro game manual mechanic and that apparently had one big compelling puzzle (which I'll circle back to), that's about it! This is the type of game where you are doing yourself a huge disservice if you spoil yourself so my biggest advice is: [b] DON'T LOOK UP ANYTHING, DON'T LOOK UP SOLUTIONS EITHER! [/b] All I'll say is if you're stuck/lost: "When in doubtie, game manual-ie outie". The game is very smart in the sense that at all times you are given everything you need to progress further, the manual pages are very selectively given to you at certain times to give you all the knowledge you need ([b]so a hint is to always look at what page you found last and ask yourself why[/b]). 

And knowledge really is the biggest "power" you will be given. I was always so excited to receive a new page of the manual and analyze it as much as possible with my current knowledge of the game. Also worth knowing is that you do not need to decipher the manual language to beat the game with the good ending. You also do not need to understand every puzzle/scribbly note in the manual to beat it either. I completed some post-game/side puzzles that I got through using the hints in the manual (that do indeed make you feel like a genius), but there is tons in there just for the pure love of hard af puzzles. There is a whole rabbit hole of secret puzzles and insanity that the community has unearthed online that is worth looking into only [b]AFTER[/b] you finish the game. But safe to say, you only need to understand [b]some[/b] of the manual puzzles/hints to finish the game and that is always connected to a repeating phrase/word, a whole page spread, etc. The game manual is very clear as to what's important and much more subtle about the extra fun notes/small hints to bonus puzzles. 

The game also has some awesome boss fights that have the difficulty fine tuned to challenge you but never make you despair and stop playing. I will say though, some of the boss hit boxes could be finicky and your attacks don't always hit despite not being physically possible to get closer to the boss/weak point. Leading up to each of the boss encounters there is so much visual storytelling and world building as you go from zone to zone, each weirder than the last. I was constantly at awe and curious about why this world is the way it is. There are few moments of "revelations" as well that are purely visual/environment storytelling that had me asking so many questions and made me very invested in the lore of the world. As a huge sucker for cryptic visually driven storytelling that doesn't give you all the answers but forces you to theorize, this game scratched just the right itch!

Lastly, I want to talk about the "last" puzzle and the ending, but do not spoil yourself if you haven't figured it out yet as it's by far the most satisfying part of the game to figure out on your own. [spoiler] The most amazing aspect of the Mountain Door puzzle is that it all comes back down to everything the game has been teaching you so far: be observant, be curious, question everything that sticks out, the answers are always right in front of you. The moment you notice the golden path has been right there the whole time, the feeling is absolutely amazing. It got me busting out the pen and paper and drawing it all out and I kind of love that the game required me to do that! I can't remember the last time I had to do something like that and it felt very rewarding. Inputting the code though felt more difficult  than the boss fights lol, but hearing the little ding and finding the first page of the manual with the dev note...what a fantastic feeling you could only ever experience once! The knowledge you end up gifting to the Heir to get the good ending being the game manual you analyzed and learned from in order to complete it is just such a wonderful way to bring things full circle. Definitely a gaming experience that will stick with me for awhile![/spoiler] 
I will say though, the puzzles/ world secrets in this game definitely lean towards the visual pattern-breaking observation kind of thinking and if that is not how your brain works this game's puzzle hints may not make a whole lot of sense to you. My brain clicks with that type of thinking and puzzle solving very well so it was all immensely satisfying throughout the game!

TL;DR Amazing game, fantastic world, joyous game manual, smart puzzles that make brain go brrr, brb going to buy the fox plushie now

I'll start by saying that Tunic is designed to be played blindly, and you'll ruin the experience the moment you look up any sort of guide whatsoever. There's no tutorial or even any real sense of direction at first, with the game even going as far as to force you to find pages of the manual on your own. Some people drop Tunic within the first few minutes because [i]waaaaah, there's no waypoint for me to follow and no mission objective to tell me what to do and there's no multiplayerrrr[/i] and that's perfectly fine because Tunic is made for people that actually enjoy it when a game assumes that they're an intelligent human being. Figuring things out by trial and error is, at least for me, refreshing and rewarding. I like it TO A POINT, a point which Tunic admittedly does reach towards the end of the game, but it's still good overall. I was able to at least beat the game without the use of a guide, but I DID have to go back and use a guide to [spoiler]actually...beat the game.[/spoiler]

Nature of the gameplay aside, Tunic has a lot of other things going for it. The colorful and minimalistic graphics get the job done, and the soundtrack is phenomenal. Tunic is certainly unique, and even though it draws inspiration heavily from Zelda and Dark Souls, it's able to use those elements as a springboard to become its own thing rather than being a simple clone. If you're okay with being frustrated by design, Tunic is an ultimately rewarding experience even if it has the occasional brief misstep along the way. I say it's worth a look if ya want something fresh!

tl;dr: A really interesting game that tries to recreate the "no instructions" gameplay style of some retro games. The design choices feel well thought out and intentional, however, for that same reason I can see people loving or hating it. Overall, I enjoyed the game myself but the longer answer to how is nuanced since there were aspects of the design choices I was not enthused about.

First off, going in blind is definitely part of the experience with Tunic. You are given no information starting off and you simply have to meander to figure out what to do and where to go. Even then, the instructions you receive are in the form of "game manual" pages scattered throughout the world which can at times be cryptic themselves. It is a neat concept but also not for me. The lack of descriptions on gameplay mechanics and items (unless you stumble upon a relevant page) was intriguing at first but eventually grew tiresome. I don't blame that on the game since it's clearly very intentional; so it's purely a matter of personal preference. I got to the second boss before looking anything up, at which point I started looking up information. I was one of the people that did not even figure out there was a leveling system until I saw it mentioned online, so I was basically playing on extra-hard difficulty until then... That said, I don't regret both playing blind up to that point or looking up info from then on.

The combat, stat system, and item system are standard RPG stuff. They are pretty good and well implemented. Well, at least once you figure out the details from trial and error, in-game manual pages, or looking them up... I played with a keyboard and you could tell at times some things were clearly designed with controllers first in mind. No big deal since that's somewhat standard for these kinds of games and it did not block me from anything but something to be aware of.

The story was simple but fun. I don't have much to add there. Similarly, I liked the graphics and soundtrack but there wasn't anything extraordinary me to call out about them.

The last thing I will mention is that there are tons of secrets in the game. Some of these are required for the true ending although most are just for fun. These secrets follow the same principle of being hidden behind cryptic instructions or puzzles in the manual pages you find throughout the world. I found some secrets on my own but I also looked up a bunch of them because I was curious to know and also wanted to get the true ending without needing to do sweeps of the map and manual pages to figure out what I was missing. If you enjoy in-game puzzles like that though, you might really enjoy that aspect as well.

All in all, Tunic knows exactly what it wants to be, and I think it does a great job at it. The only thing is whether that game design style appeals to a given player or not since it's very different from most modern games.

Suddenly, for story reasons, all your powerups are taken away, your stats are reset to base levels, and you are ushered in to a previously inaccessible area. I found this frustrating, but adapted, "got good", and made my way to the next area, hoping the game would soon return to its previous form.

This means that you have to heal after every single hit, and even if you do, after about 3 hits everything will one-hit-KO you. It's made worse by you having to fight shadowy versions of yourself who don't have a stamina bar to manage, can endlessly dodge-roll-counterattack you, and have the ability to instantly chain a thrust onto any basic attack (something you can NOT do). Even after swallowing my pride and turning combat difficulty down in the options (something I *hate* having to do; a properly-balanced game doesn't need an "Easy" setting, but I digress) the problems weren't alleviated, as all this did was change the number of hits before a OHKO to about 5 or 6, and didn't change the nature of combat at all. A good game that feels like it could be a great game if it wasn't held back by some bizarre and frustrating game design choices.

Most of the game's text is in a made-up alphabet, leaving it unreadable without a guide. I think this was supposed to simulate playing an imported game in a language you don't understand, but it just makes the game frustrating to play since you have extremely minimal guidance on what any items do (it isn't always obvious even when you use them), how your abilities work, or even where to go to advance the story. There are even entire gameplay systems that you won't learn about without looking it up, including a stat upgrade system that is mandatory to stand a chance against bosses, but can only be discovered by happening to press the right (unprompted) button in the right map location or by looking it up.

Bosses are a HUGE difficulty spike every time, being endurance battles about dodging and whittling down their health while common enemies are more hack-n-slash in how you deal with them. It creates a bit of dissonance and makes boss battles feel out of place with the rest of the game. Your items don't reset after a loss either, so be ready to grind for gold and hike back to a shop.

Some mechanics are very hit-or-miss with whether they'll function as intended for you, with the shield not always blocking attacks for some reason and the invincibility period at the beginning of a dodge roll sometimes being completely ignored, especially by bosses. Locking onto enemies is also wonky since you can't pick which one to lock onto, which makes fighting multiple enemies needlessly tough as you get slaughtered by something six inches away but can only lock onto another enemy across the room.

There's fun to be had here, but you'd best at least have some online hints handy because you'll either have to look everything up or spend ~70% of your playtime running around aimlessly hoping to stumble on what you're supposed to do next with no indication of what that is.

It's exploration turned into busywork, especially when a lot of the rewards for doing it are just money and the occasional consumable. The mystique and intrigue that Zelda dungeons create is quite absent from this game and the bosses don't really do anything to balance that out.

The puzzle element is mysteriously absent from this game, despite being tagged as so, unless the dev's idea of a puzzle is trawling through an area just to flip a switch. This game is as much a puzzle game as dark souls is if you consider opening doors from the other side or knocking down a ladder is a puzzle element. I haven't played through the whole game, so maybe all the actual puzzles are later, which is a failing of a game aiming to be and is lauded as a puzzle game.

Of the bosses I've encountered, only 1 really felt all that well designed with the others having major issues with the camera that make focusing or moving accurately far more difficult than it should be. Imagine trying to beat a group of enemies whilst your camera is spinning just so it can keep the boss on the same place in view. You have no control of the camera throughout the game and it's just for the cinematic aesthetic and  hiding things out of sight. I'd also recommend turning off depth of field for at least the boss fights. The effect is way overdone and often leaved the boss and the environment blurry unless you're up in its face.

The combat overall doesn't feel particularly great. It's relatively basic and of a similar vein to that of Zelda but they've tried to make it more challenging. Personally, I don't find it all that interesting or challenging after you get to grips with the general feel. There's not anything fundamentally flawed about it, just nothing that makes it something I actively want to do more of. Most encounters practically can be attempted the same way with a handful of enemies needing something other than your sword and shield to initiate. I've enjoyed a number of Zelda games, but so far, this game has too much of an emphasis on combat without making it interesting. The game forces you to do things different very infrequently. It's only when you get to boss fights do you actually have to use your brain in a meaningful way. Where in many other games, the encounters you have leading up to a boss will teach you things that are useful when facing the boss. In this game, every boss (of the ones I've faced) have been completely blind and will be the first time you actually need to use core mechanics. To me, this means a significant portion of the real challenge in the boss fights is in learning the mechanics in the middle of a boss fight (or relearning them because you haven't had to use them in a long time). This only creates needless frustration and means the devs could make simpler bosses with the illusion of difficulty.

The game takes an old school approach to tutorials in this game, relying on a manual to communicate mechanics, objectives and the like, but the manual is built into the game and you have to collect the pages as you play. The execution of this is mostly well done. You get more pages as you explore. It's one of the few actually meaningful rewards you get for exploring outside of upgrades and equipment. That's not to say it's flawless. At the start of the game, you're given very little direction, aside from a few pages in the manual. This manual is mostly written using pictures and a cryptic unreadable language with the occasional interpretable thing or english word. There's a lot of guesswork that goes into understanding what the manual is going on about and on a number of occasions, I only understood the actual point until I had already done the thing, practically making portions of the manual redundant.

The game is also specifically advertises its soundtrack as a point to buy the game. I love a good soundtrack. A good soundtrack can be the cherry on top in a truly awesome game or can save an average game from too many bad reviews. Hollow Knight, Vermintide 1 and 2, Link's Awakening, and Octopath Traveler are a few games that come to mind with great soundtracks. This game's soundtrack is a bit of a let down without even considering those prior mentioned games. It's just okay. It's a bit of background music. It doesn't do all that much to set and maintain the atmosphere. It is truly just an accessory to accompany the rest of the game. It is not a soundtrack that is worth my money.

All of this is to say that in my experience, there isn't much to cry home about. It relies on an old school way of designing games which is absent from modern game design and that alone seems to be one of the major features that people love about the game. I think it has plenty of flaws and is far from a perfect game, but people are willing to overlook that because of the different design philosophy used in this game. There's very little hand holding. All the gameplay is reliant on exploration and using your brain when you're stuck. With all that said, I am mostly enjoying the game. It's not amazing but I am entertained and I don't feel like I'm wasting my time most of the time. If what I've said above doesn't sound all that bad to you and you want an exploration/combat game with very little hand holding and some occasional difficulty, then it's probably the game for you. I'd still recommend waiting for a sale though (larger than the 30% at the time of this review).

Man I love this game.  On first glance, it appears to be an isometric Zelda clone where you play as Fox Link, and it is, but it's so much more.  The game is just so smartly designed.

You start off on the beach with no items, no direction, no story, no nothing.  It's up to you to find out where to go, what to do, how to win, and how deep you want to delve into the world.  It completely respects the intelligence of the player and spoon feeds you very, very little.

The game most resembles Zelda 1 of all things.  You know, the one you couldn't beat without reading the instruction manual?  Well, this game also has an instruction manual, that you collect the pages of in game.  It  details the maps of areas, how to play, the controls, the steps you need to take to complete the main game, and all the secrets.

Except for one thing.  The game isn't in English.  It's in Tunicese.  If you've ever had to play an unlocalized game from Japan, like if, say, some mediocre publisher never localized it and you had to use some bootleg ROM (*coughSuperRobotWars*) then you know that maybe 10% of the text and interface would be in English, and with enough intuition and trial and error you could figure out how to play the game.

I was not expecting this game to so accurately reflect such an experience but it does, gloriously.  By putting together snippets of readable text, along with the pictures and things you notice in game, you can figure out almost everything.  The game relies on it, because while you also have your standard Zelda items that unlock ability to traverse the map in ways you couldn't before (hook shot, etc) many times you had the ability inside you all along - you just didn't KNOW it yet.  Shortcuts that you could have always used were hidden just out of sight and you'll be startled you never noticed they were there.

So when you finally figure out how to perform some new skill it completely recontextualizes a lot of the things you've seen in the game so far.  Knowledge is just as powerful as some new magic item.  It reminds me a lot of The Outer Wilds and it's just so well done in this game.

You figure out the secrets, you unravel the story, you earn every breakthrough.  Or you could look it up online, but really that ruins the fun.  There's a few optional puzzles that are sketchy logicwise that I had to check solutions for but the vast majority of things can be figured out just by paying attention and keen observation.  It's so enjoyable.  This game is a gem.

141155235.review:
[h1]FoxMania: The Quest To Review All Fox Games On Steam![/h1]

[i]Conditions for inclusion:
[list]
[*]The player character must be consistently a fox; the fox must not be merely a skin or a character option
[*]Must have 100% working Steam achievements
[*]Must not be a visual novel
[/list][/i]

[b]Game #11: TUNIC[/b]

So you think you're a cute little fox who wakes up on the beach of a mysterious new land, ready for a delightful little Zelda-like adventure? Well... that's not exactly what you're going to get. 

Right at the beginning, something feels off -- both about the world itself, and about the way the game feeds you information about what you're supposed to do next. Why does it feel so confusing just to find a sword and get out of the starting area? Why does the world feel so empty? Who's that spirit trapped in the hexagon prison? Why is the village abandoned and inhabited by moblins? Where the heck is your minimap? What the heck is this weird language on the signposts, are you supposed to be able to read this? Does it ever get translated? 

Most importantly, why does it feel like the game is already beaten by someone else, the grand adventure is already over and done, and you're just following in some hero's footsteps? Seriously, what's going on? Why is the game designed like this?

Not even ten minutes into the game, you'll have so many hanging questions. And guess what? The game isn't going to tell you any of the answers. They're for you to figure out. ...Yeah. It's [i]that[/i] kind of a game.

If you want some answers, maybe you can take a look at the game's instruction booklet. There's some valuable info in there about basic game controls, like how to use certain items or lock onto enemies in combat. Just one problem -- the instruction booklet is torn up into individual pages and scattered around the world. Good luck with that. Not even the game's basic controls and mechanics are free info. 

See, this is no Zelda-like; it's a puzzle game disguised as a Zelda-like. I've heard some people also call this a Souls-like, and while I'm not entirely sure I agree, it does strongly remind me a lot of La-Mulana in the way it forces you to look at the world differently when you're desperate for answers. It's quite satisfying to slowly absorb and internalize the way the game hides its secrets and communicates its ideas. And once you learn something, there's a special kind of joy in realizing that it was [i]always[/i] true... and it's a lot of fun to imagine what you could do with certain information on a new playthrough if you knew it from the very start.

The game's artistry is what I'd call perfect. The graphics are cute when they want to be, hauntingly powerful when they want to be. I especially liked the instruction booklet artwork, a perfect parody of what it's referencing. The soundtrack is expansive and masterful, though it leans more towards ambience than catchiness, so there are only a few tracks that will actually get stuck in your head. There's a deep story to unravel here, too. I dare not spoil anything, but I'll simply say that it's got moments that'll strike hard, it's absolutely not what you're expecting, and it's a lot more than you bargained for.

As for criticisms: 

[list]
[*]It's obvious the designers put a lot of effort into keeping the combat system simple and unintrusive, and while that works perfectly fine for exploring the world and solving the game's ridiculous puzzles, I find the combat a bit [i]too[/i] uninteresting when it's placed front and center, like for certain boss battles. 

[*]It's not far-off to say that "every copy of TUNIC is personalized". The game is built around letting you progress surprisingly far without having found key items or knowing basic information, and while this [i]mostly[/i] works, I feel it sometimes goes a bit too far in withholding information from the player. Depending on certain paths taken, it's not always reasonable to expect the player to infer knowledge they were supposed to find ten hours ago. It works a lot, just not always.

[*]While I didn't encounter any intrusive bugs in-game, the UI has some very strange bugs, ranging from showing incorrect item counts on the pause menu, to sometimes even loading the wrong file on the file select screen. Baffling! 
[/list] 

[i]TUNIC[/i] obviously wanted to be a masterpiece, and it came [i]so close[/i] to being one. Though I feel it stumbles a little at the finish line, it's absolutely still worth experiencing. If this looks the least bit interesting to you, I invite you to dive right in. It lasts about 20 hours, and is guaranteed to blow your mind more than once. Just go in with the right expectations: this is a puzzle game, not a Zelda clone. If you want some top-tier bragging rights, see if you can get all the pages, fairies, and secret items without looking at a guide. (Tip: while you can get through the main story on your own, better grab a pen and a notebook if you're going for any of the game's bonus collectables. You'll need it.)

I'm very happy to have played this. I know this one's going to stick with me for a while. 

8 / 10.
