Tunic is a game that hasn't left my head since I finished it.
It's a stellar game that thrives off of "Ah-Ha" moments. The entire game is one big maze- the path may seem straightforwards at first, but then when you get stumped, there's always a new path you'd missed. You may not have seen that path if you didn't gain the new information the old path taught you. The world is filled to the brim, so much so, there are secrets INSIDE the secrets. There's always something new to be found and gained.
The music takes you inside the world, its very neutral pacing allowing you to ruminate at the wall you've been trying to get around for the past 20 minutes without it getting grating or irritating. The game is meant to be a puzzle in every sense, pushing you in the same directions you've been, and giving you resources to a puzzle you don't know exist. Every minute I played this game was a nother minute that I was captured by its charm, and surprised at every little twist and turn the game had to offer. Was it hard when I got stuck? Yes. Was it annoying? Also yes- but it was never to a point where I wanted to remove myself from the game. Everything was always in reach, and if one path yielded nothing, I knew I could go back to an area I had combed 3 times over and find something new all over.
The story itself keeps very hidden, which to me was a bit of a disappointment. I'm someone who loves games for their story, and that's not the kind of game that Tunic is. There are aspects of Environmental Storytelling in the booklet and areas within the game, but no part of the story is directly discernible. To me that's part of the game- I realize that now. It gives itself to hypothesis, being a new puzzle to explore once you feel ready, or come to your own conclusions about the story as you play. The story is never outright spelled out for you, but just to a higher extent than you'd expect from other similarly narratively-structured games like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight. In those games, the story is present everywhere and can be deciphered through painstaking research, the story of Tunic is less so. This was initially disappointing, but as I look back on my experience, I'm grateful that I had the opportunity to craft a story of my own through bites of context. That's not something a lot of games get right these days.
To summarize; Tunic is a game for EVERYONE. There is an experience to be found for the puzzle solver, the combat enthusiast, the story driven... It's a game that's just right in almost every regard, and I'm grateful I stopped to play the game.

[i]Tunic[/i] is an exercise into making cryptic nonsense enjoyable. Unlike a lot of games in this "cryptic puzzle" genre, such as [i]La-Mulana[/i] and [i]The Witness[/i], [i]Tunic[/i] cleverly embeds it's puzzle solving into the game by presenting it in a unique way; make the answers incredibly obvious, but completely obfuscate them.

[i]Tunic[/i] is a Zelda-like exploration RPG where the major twist is that you have an in-game manual. Not just a "heres how to play the game" manual, but a full on guide, full of maps, secrets, and important details. The manual is written in a cipher language that you cannot understand, forcing the player to instead rely on visual cues and tiny clues hidden throughout the book to progress. This is, in a single word, enthralling. The game has quite literally every answer for every puzzle stuffed into this guide somewhere, making the act of even picking up a page exciting. Some of the puzzles in this game use the manual in fascinating and engrossing ways, and even outside of the puzzles the manual is used to excellent effect. You get foreshadowing, atmosphere, useful tips and practical advice from this thing, making it a constant companion in your journey. The integration of the manual into the puzzle design is nothing short of genius and it is easily [i]Tunic[/i]'s most successful idea. 

Unfortunately, that's all of [i]Tunic[/i]'s qualities I can fully praise. Everything else is divisive. To sum it up quickly, [i]Tunic[/i] slowly shifts from an exploration-based game to a puzzle-based one. While I personally liked this, quite a few people strongly disliked this shift, feeling as though the qualities they liked about the game were phased out for something else. I wouldn't call this false advertising, more like a shift in priorities. It honestly feels like all the meaningful exploration is just there to set up the puzzles, which can feel disheartening when you realise how repetitive some of the puzzles can be. Using the puzzle as a guidebook while exploring or figuring out where to go next is awesome, using it to do most of the lategame puzzles really isn't. Even though I liked the shift to the puzzle focus, I can't really say I enjoyed it more than the exploration of the first three quarters.

Still, I really freaking loved this game. The manual idea alone is ingenius, and all of the concepts surrounding the game and its cultivated mystique are executed perfectly. Even if [i]Tunic[/i] didn't hit all the beats I wanted it to, and ultimately moved away from what I felt was a very strong design focus, I cannot deny that it succeeded in what it wanted to accomplish: inspiring genuine wonder and awe in a guy who's been playing games before he could walk.

On the surface this looks like a typical Zelda-like, and in some ways it is very reminiscent of older Zelda titles like A Link to the Past. What makes this game stand out however isn't in it's similarities to Zelda games, but rather in it's differences.


Much like Outer Wilds, this is one of those games where I can't give you too much information without spoiling major aspects of the game. In fact, that is the very premise the game is built around. Despite the Zelda-like layout and Souls-like combat, the core of this game revolves around information. Everything in this game is written in an undecipherable wingding language, leaving the player guessing as to what signs mean throughout the world. More importantly though, as you go through the game, you'll find pages of the game's "instruction manual", being very reminiscent of the manuals in older NES/SNES titles. This manual is also mostly in this wingding language, forcing the player to decipher meanings from the pictures, other pages, and context clues. While you may think this sounds annoying upon reading this review, let me assure you that this is excellently pulled off, making you want to find these manual pages and keeping you thinking about what some enigmatic riddle could mean long after you've put the game down. When you do figure something new out, the "Ah-Ha!" moment is unparalleled and you feel like a genius.
The only time these manual puzzles become really over the top to solve is in the post-game for the "good" ending. I did not actually manage to solve all of these, but despite it, I never found it too frustrating to go on, and if anything makes me even more determined to eventually go back and solve that mystery.

Beyond that, I can tell you that while there aren't that many boss fights, they are quite enjoyable and visually pleasing. The exploration in this game is top notch. Truly this is a game I would recommend to nearly everyone. One of the best games in every genre it falls into.

Reminds me of a cross between a Link to the Past and Fez. A key difference is that, although you still collect items to help you traverse the world, the true primary thing you collect is information about the game, which is learned via pages of the instruction manual scattered across the world. As a result, you should ABSOLUTELY go in blind if you don't want to spoil a lot of the information-based puzzles throughout the game. Puzzles are altogether not terribly difficult, and the game loooves hiding stuff just out of sight of the isometric view, so if strafing walls and shifting camera angles regularly pisses you off, this might sour your experience a bit. One thing to note is that the instruction manual, and nearly all text in game, is in a foreign script, so the primary "puzzle" is critically examining context clues you find in the manual and around you to understand what's going on and what to do. That said, the game still does a very good job directing you along the critical path without relying on you finding obscure secrets, so if you do want to just breeze through without searching for and finding every little hidden thing, there are plenty enough breadcrumbs for that. At worst, if you have slacked on finding pages, you may find yourself in an area without a map, but this still works find so long as you aren't trying to find every secret in the area.

From a mechanical standpoint, the game is a fair bit more challenging than Zelda, and combat has a "weightier" feel akin to Dark Souls that encourages you to precisely use I-frames in dodge-rolls to avoid damage or be heavily punished. Bosses in particular can be very challenging, and force you to really learn their patterns well before you have even a chance to win against them.

Overall, an absolutely fantastic experience and a remarkable example of good, hands-off game design that teaches the player by allowing them to learn themselves via subtle, precise guidance. If you are at all a fan of 2D Zeldas games, or just adventure games in general, this is a must play!

Un viaje encantador a la simplicidad sublime

Tunic, anteriormente conocido como Secret Legend, es una obra maestra que combina una jugabilidad hermosa con escenarios impresionantes. Con un encanto irresistible y puzzles ingeniosos, Tunic logra capturar la grandeza en lo simple y ofrece una experiencia memorable para los jugadores. Está inspirado en los clásicos juegos de la saga Legend of Zelda con una combinación de Souls.

Tunic presenta una jugabilidad maravillosamente diseñada que es fácil de aprender pero difícil de dominar. Desde el primer momento, te encontrarás inmerso en un mundo encantador, tranquilo y lleno de vida. Cada movimiento, cada acción se siente fluida y ágil, lo que te permite explorar libremente los bellos escenarios y enfrentarte a desafiantes enemigos. La atención al detalle en los controles y la respuesta instantánea a tus comandos contribuyen a una experiencia de juego excepcional.

Los escenarios de Tunic son simplemente impresionantes. Desde bosques misteriosos hasta ruinas antiguas y paisajes pintorescos, cada ubicación está meticulosamente diseñada con una estética visual encantadora. Los colores vibrantes y la iluminación atmosférica se combinan para crear un ambiente mágico que te sumerge por completo en el mundo del juego. Cada rincón está lleno de detalles sorprendentes que te incitan a explorar más y descubrir los secretos ocultos.

Aunque el juego presenta una mecánica de juego sencilla, logra cautivarte con su encanto minimalista y su enfoque en los elementos fundamentales. I don't have a lot of playtime yet but I do feel like I've formulated a pretty good idea of what the game is about after going in completely blind (I beat the first key holding boss as of this review). I also received this game as a birthday gift (thank you!!)

To keep things short up front, this game is a love letter to exploration games like zelda while making use of the fromsoft souls formula for a lot of the game's mechanics, in a stripped down way. There are pros and cons to this. The world keeps you wanting to explore for no reason other than "I wonder what lies ahead?" This will be very familiar to fans of souls games, and you may find yourself right at home.

Now, for the long part. A lot is subjective person-to-person so I'll lay out the more prominent things I experienced. 

The game has an obscured language that slowly reveals itself as you discover pages of the lost instruction manual. It very much starts out feeling like you're playing a foreign untranslated game and you have to guess and experiment with how items work, and there are many hidden mechanics you'll have to puzzle out yourself. There have already been a few instances where I had to return to an area later because an obscure mechanic or puzzle solution was hidden and only hinted at in a page of the instruction manual found much later. And by obscure, I don't mean hints about a puzzle you could brute force, I mean arbitrarily obscure. As in, hold a random button for 5 seconds in a specific place so something will happen. Spoilers: [spoiler] You can tell the one that annoyed me the most is the prayer mechanic that moves the big pillars and allows fast travel on the golden plates. It is fine on its own but felt entirely random and came out of nowhere. [/spoiler]

The combat is really tough and took some getting used to because it is clunky at times. Not DS1 clunky, but actual clunky. Enemies hit like a truck in the early game when you have nothing but a stick and no hp upgrades. Sometimes the lock on makes you strafe instead of rotate to face the enemy. There is little telegraphing in enemy attacks because of the basic art style, save for some of the sword enemies. The big problem though, is the enemies don't really scale up too much once you find the items that make it easier to fight them (getting the shield and wand makes fighting encounters WAY smoother, to the point of trivializing them). This is also not a souls game where dodge rolling is king; in fact I only use the dodging to reposition because of the poor iframes. It's more reliable to focus on positioning and blocking rather than actual dodging. None of this was bad enough to push me away, but it did come close until I found the sword and shield. I can very well see the early game dissuading others.

There are many hidden paths and rooms all over the place, which is neat and rewards a careful eye and exploration. That said, there is definitely a pattern of "if a corner of a room is obscured by the walls/camera angle, there is at least a 60% chance something is hidden there" which, again, is a little cheap but at least consistent. Illusory walls in souls games are pretty much an immersion breaking meme but at least this game integrates secrets a bit better into the game world itself.

Visually, the game looks great. No major comments here. I especially like the art style of the instruction booklet. Very nostalgic!

This game is a tough recommend unless you're used to the game language of souls games and don't require much direction to feel fulfilled. Exploration can feel rewarding despite knowing nothing about what you're doing or why you're doing it. You will have to want to play the game to enjoy it and uncover the mysteries held within it. I haven't even beaten the game and I have no idea if the ending will even be worth it, but its been fun so far. If this doesn't put you off, I would absolutely give this game a try.

[u] ☆ The [b] Style [/b]. [/u] I generally believe that in almost any case, a hand drawn 2D version could look better then any 3D modeled version. Tunic is not one of these cases. [/spoiler] A game between you and the developers who put so much time, effort, a part of their lives into it. [spoiler] It's a conversation with no words. A game in a language you can't read. As someone who has loved A Link to the Past since childhood, I was skeptical of all of the praise of this being a good successor. After playing it through and eating every puzzle it has to offer, the praise is quite warranted. The puzzles are more mature and complicated and there is less item progression compared to ALttP, however I do not feel the game suffers for it. It is not totally similar to ALttP and similar games but I feel that it really scratched the same itch of a million secrets and things to explore.

The combat is enjoyable and the bosses feel the right amount of difficult, however on keyboard re-focusing is a little cumbersome, but there is only one fight which benefits from doing it so it isn't a huge problem.

The story is the weak point of the game however that doesn't mean it is unenjoyable. I don't feel the lack of a great story detracts from the game experience and the story still has a couple of "Oh wow" or "Aww cute" moments which will stick with me.

The game is extremely rewarding for someone who loves devouring puzzles, returning to areas, noting little things that don't quite seem right, and watching everything come together in the end. You are given no direction, no instruction, and no goals by the game. This game will not hold your hand, not in the hardcore way, but in a way that makes you feel like you are able to do all things at your own pace and really makes you feel special each time you discover something new entirely on your own.

There is a lot going on in the puzzle department and a lot of areas to return to, so this game might be a bit tricky to come back to after putting it down for a month or something. You know its a good puzzle game when you get out the pencil and paper notebook, and this is one of those, so don't be afraid to write down stuff!

The manual adds a ton of charm to the game and everything feels lovingly crafted. I cannot recommend the game highly enough. I hope they will make something similar in the future. Thank you TUNIC team for your hard work and love!

I might be a little obsessed.)

Tunic's one of my favorite games of all time, rounding out a puzzle adventure trifecta of all-time greats (with Fez, which it resembles in a lot of ways, and Outer Wilds, which it doesn't). The art's lovely and sweet, the music is gorgeous (it's my go-to background soundtrack for games with bad music), the puzzles are incredibly clever, and the combat is great. 

The story has a light touch. Personally, that's the one thing I'd probably consider a flaw - I prefer a story that gets into a bit more depth, maybe one with a few characters to get to know. But what's there is good and meaningful. 

But the one thing that really, really stands out for me is the in-game manual. I grew up on SNES games, which all came with these lovely, illustrated manuals that felt like they held all the games secrets. Tunic's manual is nostalgic, but it's also better than the original - those old game manuals mostly just felt like they were full of secret wisdom. Tunic's manual genuinely is. For me, nothing beats the feeling of discovering the solution to a puzzle through a mix of clever hints and genuine breakthroughs, and Tunic layers those on top of each other like it's effortless.

Anyhow, I love this little fox game. You should check it out.

TUNIC is a game that felt like it promised to be my game, and then said "I lied!" 10 hours later.

What everyone recommends is that you go into TUNIC blind and free of walkthroughs, which I agree with, but from what you can see from trailers and the steam page is that it's a bit of a 2D Zelda clone with a manual that you can't read and secrets everywhere. That's good! I used to love those games and felt like this sort of exploration of old games' level design was a very fun idea.

And the game exectutes this fairly well! The manual pages are fun to find and the secrets can be wonderful to figure out yourself, some many hours after you already had the opportunity to do something with them. A lot of people mention how this makes it so getting lost is way too easy, and yes, it is, but I think that is to be expected if you want the ideal experience with this game. Fuck, go play the first Zelda on the NES, are you not lost?

The problem is something else entirely. Because exploration and cryptic puzzles simply isn't enough to make this game entertaining (debatable), TUNIC has a lot of combat too. A sword and a shield, magic items, a dodge roll, and every type of enemy attacking you that you can think of. You heal through flask-like items, and using checkpoints makes enemies respawn. Sound familiar?

Unfortunately, TUNIC's combat is an intrusive mess, a complete "fuck you" to the player with very easy to understand but mechanically unfair fights. Every enemy encounter is potentially fatal, and they're all okay at best and "immediately closing the application" at worst. Out of, what, 5 or 6 boss fights I did, only 1 was all that interesting. Fuck, at some point they even give you [spoiler]enemies who make your health bar smaller if you get hit. Are you serious? What is this design?[/spoiler]

It is upsetting to me how much a game so unashamed of showing its influences can also feel so afraid of having simple zelda-like combat. This game should not have been a soulslike. Its hostility towards the player can make some sense thematically, but is so frustrating that I've tried three times to give this game another chance and failed. I got to one of the parts people consider to be "when the game gets good" but at that point my patience had wore down so much that I couldn't bear to keep going.

If you want to get this anyway but consider my opinion on this worth a listen, just... Don't be afraid to just use the invincibility. The fact that it's an option right there from the moment you start means something.

I just wish TUNIC was a game about exploring areas and solving puzzles. It isn't.

138124587.review:
This has quickly become one of my favourite games ever. It is absolutely outstanding. 
This game does not give you a lot to go off. You don't really know anything when you start, but it gives you just enough as you go through the game to piece everything together. It's an interesting idea which a lot of games try to do, but i personally feel like this is one of the only times that it has actually been done well.
By giving you a user manual in a cryptic language, it gives you guidance, but makes you figure it out yourself. It's such a unique approach. It explains everything, absolutely everything, but does so in a way that still requires you to figure it all out for yourself. This is such an innovative way of doing instruction, explanation, and guidance, and it works shockingly well. It is engaging, interesting, and uninvasive.
I do however think that this feature is a massive hit or miss sort of thing, with some serious downsides, and the potential to ruin the game for some people. You will frequently find yourself getting lost while playing, and remaining lost for a while until you find what it is that you missed. You won't know if you're just missing something obvious, or if you're in the wrong part of the world entirely. The frequent confusion followed by aimless wandering definitely gets quite tiresome and frustrating, but overall i think this is an extremely cool part of the game.

The storytelling is done in a similar way. It's engaging, and it's presented in a way that I can only describe by calling it art. It has you experience the story rather than being told it, which i absolutely love.

The visuals are just stunning. A very unique and stylised aesthetic which looks beautiful, has serious love and attention put into it, and doesn't require a supercomputer to run well. 

The combat isn't good, but it's okay. This is where the similarities to dark souls hurt the game. The dodging, attacking, blocking, parrying, and healing are all so slow and clunky, and the game could be better with a more fast paced combat system, BUT, it works okay in this. The enemy attacks are very well telegraphed, both visually and aurally, and there are well defined patterns. The mechanics which may not be immediately obvious are understood after checking the manual, the hitboxes are accurate, and the animations are good. The clunkiness is a definite negative, but the combat is built around it better than most games that have the same issue, so unlike those games, it's quite manageable here. Once you get comfortable with it, it feels fine.

Audio is great, the music goes from intense to eerie to beautiful so smoothly, and the sound effects do an outstanding job at making you feel immersed.

The physics give a good feeling of polish to the game, but at the same time, can be a bit detrimental. For example, I got stuck completely at one spot because some debris blocked the path up and I just couldn't push it out of the way for some reason. It's cool seeing pots shatter to pieces that all move independently, and it's cool being able to make use of the physics by doing things such as rolling explosive barrels into a group of enemies, but the fact that these pieces can create roadblocks feels like a bit of an oversight.

The world is remarkable. It is very detailed, absolutely packed with secrets, so interesting and unique, and so well made. Every section fits together so seamlessly, shortcuts are scattered around in the most convenient places, and you're constantly shown things that are just out of reach, filling you with curiosity as to how and when you will be able to reach it. And every time you are given whatever new thing you need for you to get them, it feels absolutely amazing each and every time.
It is so full of life too. There are new enemies everywhere you go, that are all so clearly tailored for that area. They're all unique and interesting, and they are perfectly suited to their environment. Paired with the stunning visuals, this has to be one of my favourite video game worlds ever.

The puzzles are absolutely genius. I thought they were amazing all game, but once i reached the post game, i was blown away. I've always struggled with puzzle games, because they never make sense to me. Rather than trying to figure out the puzzle, i'm stuck trying to figure out what the rules and mechanics of the puzzle are. Yet somehow this game which is intentionally mysterious makes perfect sense to me. I know how to figure out the puzzles, i just need to actually solve them. I'm not wasting much time questioning what I need to do. This game has the single most interesting puzzles I have ever encountered, they are outstanding. Figuring out how to open the mountain door was such a gratifying feeling.
Some of them however, or more specifically, some of the bonus collectables, are way too demanding. They vary from simply needing you to notice little details in the manual, to expecting you to study up on musical notations. I do strongly recommend trying to figure out as much of the game as you can by yourself, but by the end, it felt to me more like you as an individual are not expected to, the playerbase as a whole is. You will definitely need guidance to 100% this.

Overall, i do believe this game is a hit or miss, as the unique approach to guidance could just as easily turn people away from the game as it could attract people, and the complexity of this world and the secrets it contains may be a bit much for some. Though I think if it does hit for you, you're going to have a new top 10 favourite game. It is just so good. I very strongly recommend giving it a chance.

137422952.review:
This is a beautiful game :)
I originally purchased it because it looked absolutely gorgeous, and I was not disappointed in that regard. It has such a beautifully stylized, highly detailed, handcrafted world for you to explore. Basically every 10 square feet of this place has something important going on with it. It's not particularly big, but the stark lack of dead space here makes it feels like a continent.
But OH BOY it is so much more.
Basically everything that you need to know in order to play the game is kept a secret from you in the beginning. There is an in-game manual, but its are pages scattered throughout the world, and you need to collect them in order to get any sense of what you're doing (otherwise, it's trial and error). I'm a person who loves making secret codes and conlangs in their free time, and finding the first few pages of the manual lit that part of my brain up like a fireworks show. While there are parts of it you can get from context, more than half the thing is written in a secret language you have to solve. [i]Learning how to play this game is a puzzle.[/i]
Remember how I said every 10 square feet of this game has something important going on in it? Well, this game actually has another name, "Secret Legend", and given how many secrets there are in this game, it fits very well. While this game has been appropriately labelled a Zelda-Souls-like, it is first and foremost a game about learning secrets. There are collectible upgrades and special abilities you can access, but secrets serve as your primary means of progression. I was afraid that this would hurt the game's replayability, but here's the funny thing: IT DOESN'T. While there is a New Game+ option that makes things a bit tougher, restarting the game from scratch with a totally new save is a completely different experience, since the secrets you have learned from completing it still apply: while in-game you are as weak as you were when you first started out, you can use your old knowledge to completely overthrow the order of progression.
It is a wild experience, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves a mystery. A few things you should know, though (and keep in mind, this is a person who likes solving puzzles): 
1. If you get any pleasure from puzzle-solving, PLEASE STAY AWAY FROM INTERNET GUIDES AS MUCH AS YOU CAN. While there are a rare few who respect the player's intelligence by tastefully dropping hints, most resources you find on the Internet just give you the answer, sometimes spoiling more than you'd have liked to know. There were a few times I had to look something up (one of the late game secrets required me to know a game mechanic I should have learned in the early game),  But if you really like the thrill of solving a puzzle yourself, read the manual closely. Try different tactics and perspectives. Heck, if it's still pretty early in the game, save it for later. It might be frustrating in the moment, but once you solve it, you'll be glad you did.
2. While there are some opportunities to softlock yourself, there are even more ways to get physically stuck that aren't actually softlocks, i.e. getting temporarily stuck on a ledge or cheesing your way into an area before knowing how to get out. There are a few game mechanics that are particularly tricky on this; they've been fined-tuned to greatly reduce the likelihood, but it can still happen. Usually, getting stuck is just a matter of finagling your way out, but it you do softlock, you can just reload the save to escape them.
3. Keep an open mind going in. I went into this thinking this was going to be an ordinary adventure, but I was completely caught off guard by its sheer complexity, in more ways than one. I don't want to spoil the surprise, but all I'll say is this: This is a beautiful game, so be ready for anything.

Tunic was a bit of a disappointment for me. Maybe I was a bit too hyped for it, because, as it is, it is still an ok game and I had fun playing it. It however doesn’t innovate in any meaningful way and compared to the games it got inspired from, namely Zelda and Darksouls, it feels shallow. Even though it’s basically a combination of those two games, it doesn’t borrow their strongest elements and doesn’t manage to get the same level of excitement as either of these two titles while playing. 

As I eluded before, Tunic is an isometric dungeon crawler type of game the likes of Zelda, with many elements borrowed from Dark souls, such as the bonfire-system, the estus-flask, the mysterious barely explained narrative and maybe some small empathies on boss fights using a dodge and parry mechanic. The aesthetic of it really make it seem like it’s a Zelda-type game which has elements borrowed from Dark souls, which was what I was expecting, however it more feels like a souls-like game that has elements borrowed from Zelda. What do I mean by that?

Well for a game like that I expected something similar to the temples/dungeons found in Zelda, with some kind of puzzles and keys and new items with which to fight the bosses of said temples. Well some of Tunics levels can be thought of as dungeons or temples, but there are basically no puzzles or key-riddles in them, neither are there any new items. Tunics levels boil down to elongated hallways with a bunch of monsters to fight, the treasures found mainly elude to upgrading your characters’ base stats instead of giving a different ability or fighting style. One level I found particularly disappointing: There was one lair which totally gave me the vibe of an assassin hideout, so enemies sneaking up on me and traps and those sorts of things was what I expected…. but what I got was the same as any other level. I am all for subverting expectations, but you have to at least do something with it and not subvert it by doing nothing. I think no level in Tunic is really memorable or unique, they all kinda feel samey and not really interesting. They look nice, so the level design is nicely done, but they play very repetitively without any soul in them. 

The only thing uniquely interesting about Tunic is probably its darker world building in the second half of the game and the game journal you use to make sense of the world. The game journal however also includes the maps of dungeons, which in my opinion gave away too much if you got them before even entering the specific area.  

All the riddles in the game kinda came at the end and after figuring out how they work you have to go through every area again searching for them… it’s a very tedious job and since those riddles mostly use the same mechanic, there is not much variety in them. Overall I would say that a lot of the mysterious-solving elements of Tunic basically boil down to going over the same area over and over again until you find something new. It was not very fun to do so, which is why I didn’t finish off all the optional puzzles. 

To conclude, Tunic was a fine game, with some nice level design and the bosses very fun to fight. However it doesn't manage to stick out of the many forgettable 2D indie souls like games or the 2D indie Zelda like games.

Tunic has just about everything that I look for in a classic adventure game- tight controls, mysterious lore, vibrant visuals, and oozing with soul. The second the camera zoomed in on that little fox and the beautiful music started playing, I could instantly feel the game was going to be one to remember. I'd be lying if I said the nostalgic hook was the only thing that kept me playing, but the game has so much more to offer than just "cute little guy with a sword". The OST alone would be enough to sell it to me- it really carries you through each area and matched every one's vibe perfectly.

Echoing what some others have said, I will agree that the gameplay, while simple, is very "soulslike". I played on the normal difficulty and died dozens of times to each boss until muscle memory kicked in, then it was secondhand nature and at that point the combat got really fun. The consequence for death isn't much of a setback though, but still- go in with the mindset that you'll be learning the mechanics by dying. A lot.

Above all else however, the one thing that kept my absolutely hooked was the overarching meta "manual" collection quest, where you come across little pages of an actual game manual that subsequently also doubles as an in-game strategy guide. The more I collected, the more immersed I felt, and the more it took me back to feeling like a kid literally looking through the guides of my old favorite games. It's a very unique and charming implementation of directing the player, without being overtly direct or holding your hand (which Tunic does pretty much none of), and towards the end, I felt like a madman mulling meticulously over each page over and over again for hints to the final puzzles. And if you're like me and couldn't get enough of the manual aspect, you probably wanted a physical version (which are becoming a reality and up for preorder!)

Overall a truly amazing experience that I find my review can't do any justice- the only way is to pick this up and play it yourself.

Tunic is somewhat similar to Fez. It's eye-catching and it'll take dozens of hours before you realize that you have been cheated. What is the problem? Tunic's puzzles are very, very boring - just like the way in which the puzzles of Fez are bad. 
I liked a bit one of the twists, but overall, when you solve them instead of "Aha!" all you will feel is "Meh". 

I'm saying this as a person who likes and solves difficult logical puzzles (Snakebird, Stephen's Sausage Roll, English Country Tune, The Witness) and also likes exploration and environmental puzzles (the earliest Tomb Raiders, Indiana Jones and the Infernal Machine, the puzzle driven Zelda games, Project Eden, Ico) and of course, good 80s and 90s adventure games.

From one point on, you are basically asked to "decipher these weird patterns and symbols, or figure out this one little thing in this enormous world". If you like cryptography, interpretation and deciphering for the sake of it, with no other justification... you'd better pick up a better game that does exactly these, like The Witness (patterns) or Heaven's Vault (language). Solving them isn't hard, it just feels like a chore, even less interesting than what I do at my day job. The puzzles are also pointlessly contrived; they don't follow from the emergent properties of the world. Obfuscation and red herrings for the sake of it. And the worst part - some puzzles have clear instructions once you notice them or obtain them, but the author has no idea in how many ways his "clear instructions" can be validly interpreted (in one particular case, it's hundreds).

It's notable that Tunic sells very well because of false advertising, or, more accurately put, because of the impression of "Dark Souls meets Zelda" it creates. In reality, it is "Fez but with added combat". Both Fez and Tunic feed on the nostalgia for exploration and discovery that old games provided and do it badly.

The worst part is that you can't figure out a game like this before you have wasted your money and, more importantly, A LOT OF YOUR PRECIOUS TIME. A demo wouldn't tell you enough; someone else's opinion may be irrelevant because they may be just dumb or not into that kind of thing. This is what bothers me the most. I'm used to exploration / puzzle games being rare and good. Now I have to be paranoid about my favourite genre. Maybe that's what I paid for: I paid for this bitter lesson. But you don't have to.

Here's a game I'm rather conflicted about. It does a lot right, a few things not so much and despite having good mechanics, some of them eventually wear out their welcome.
As a throwback to the Zeldas of yester-year Tunic gets a full score with it's lush graphics, combat and exploration and initial setting and atmosphere. Fighting offers all the trappings we have come to expect in this current games industry where everyone seems compelled to copy Dark Souls, for good or ill. There's stamina, healing flasks and bosses that hit like a truck. They even included the corpse-run, which I find particularly unnecessary.
The game world is really pretty and inviting with it's soft lighting and simple, kinda squarish, angular artstyle. Exploration is done by nosing through every nook and cranny, employing gadgets and unlocking shortcuts. Curiosity is very much rewarded. One neat feature inherent in the birds-eye-view, locked-camera setup is that many secret passages are hidden behind the topography, in crevices and around corners and such. The downside is that you spend quite some time fumbling your way through these paths with nothing but a silhouette to guide you by and the rather stiff movement controls doesn't exactly help matters. And as fun as the exploration is, the backtracking you have to do at the end is rather tiresome, although I suppose it's optional.
The standout feature is obviously the in-game instruction manual. Richly illustrated, informative and immersive (it even have coffecup stains!) this booklet fleshes out the game world, teaches you how to play the game and solve puzzles and on top of it all provides a serious nostalgia kick. Some puzzles and features are quite brilliantly hidden in plain sight until you find the correct manual page telling what you can do. And since it's mostly written in a made-up tongue you still have to piece together the clues yourself. However If you're planning on 100-percenting Tunic I wish you good luck because some of those secrets are so goddamn obscure I have no idea how you're supposed to find them without a guide.
Part of the plot is also revealed in the manual and in true Soulslike fashion it's an obscure affair and frankly not terribly involving.
My biggest complaint though is the tonal shift Tunic undergoes partway through the game. It starts off with a more lighthearted setting and premise but then takes a noticably darker turn and I find it quite jarring, subjective as it may be. It feels almost like the game wants to be subversive because that's what you're supposed to do these days. I really would have preferred if the developers would have stuck to the initial impression.
So there it is, despite some design choices I don't agree with I can't deny Tunic is solid craftmanship with a lot of heart and it therefore receives my recommendation!

135866137.review:
Tunic is really two games in one.

The [b] first game [/b] is obvious - it's the Zelda-like, souls-inspired, dungeon crawler that you probably bought the game for. Exploring distinct, colorful areas, fighting enemies with basic hack-and-slash combat, finding upgrades and new progression items, solving engaging but simple puzzles, using maps to chart complex dungeons, unearthing secrets, and fighting demanding but satisfying bosses. All your Zelda staples are covered, and the game does a pretty competent job of copying the nostalgic bits from ALTTP and other Zelda games while also adding it's own twists. It also borrows the corpse run mechanic, demanding boss encounters, and parry timing from Dark Souls. The graphics are amazing, the music is nice and atmospheric, and the story is simple at first glance but becomes steadily more engaging and surreal as you progress.

I'd give this main, Zelda-like portion of the game a solid 8/10. It does most everything extremely well with some fresh ideas, but it isn't groundbreaking (with the exception of one aspect I mention below). It will definitely hit the spot for any fans of Zelda or Souls games, though. I certainly thoroughly enjoyed the adventure, though be aware the difficulty is closer to Dark Souls than Zelda.

The [b] second game [/b] is the in-game user manual that you will piece together throughout the game. This is Tunic's gimmick, the thing that makes it unique from other retro Zelda-likes. Throughout the course of the "main" game, you will find pages of this cute, Zelda 1 style manual that will give you small pieces of information and clues to push you in the right direction pr explain game mechanics. Crucially, the manual has very limited readable text, as most of the text is in an ancient runic language that is indecipherable. So you have to take the limited hints you get and read between the lines to really understand what is going on. 

The manual also acts as the game's map. You will pick up detailed map pages (complete with compass showing the player's position) of the overworld and all the main dungeon areas. You can miss pages that will help you progress, but generally the important ones are along the main path and difficult to overlook.

But that's just the beginning of the manual. Hidden deep within it's pages is a much larger puzzle, one that will consume countless hours of time beyond the main story of the game as you slowly piece together dozens of hints and clues. To complete this huge meta-puzzle, you will find yourself flipping back and forth between the manual and the game world, completing smaller puzzles scattered around the world, writing down information in a physical notebook (yes, this is one of only a few games I have played, along with La Mulana and a couple of the Myst games, that really requires you to use a notebook outside of the game to track info), and testing out hypotheses to figure out what hints are trying to tell you. Honestly, this puzzle alone is better than many puzzles from standalone puzzle games, because the answer is the culmination of everything you have accomplished and come to understand in the game since the very beginning, and it feels immensely satisfying to finally put it all together.

Even this meta-puzzle is not the end of Tunic's endless depth, though. Remember that "indecipherable" runic language that most of the manual is written in? Turns out it's not indecipherable, and you are actually able to translate the runes, which can help with a few puzzles and is absolutely mandatory for two puzzles at the very end of the game. Ultimately, deciphering the runic language and solving the huge meta-puzzle is not required to finish the "main" game (a wise decision considering most people interested in a simple Zelda clone won't have the patience to complete these mind-boggling puzzles), but it goes to show the sheer amount of depth and dedication put into a portion of the game that many players won't ever see.

The puzzle part of the game involving completing the manual was by far the more interesting and engaging part of the game for me, and I'd give this aspect an enthusiastic 10/10. It includes one of my favorite puzzles in any game ever, and I love the aspect of writing down information from across the game world and manual in a notebook to solve an overarching meta-puzzle. This portion of the game is not for everyone, but if you appreciate the ideas behind old-school adventure games like Myst or Riven or puzzle games like the Witness, this part of the game is for you. Not enough games explore this type of intense puzzle-solving that transcends the limits of the game itself, and Tunic does it very well.

[b] Overall Score: 9/10 [/b]

On one hand it's a cute lil souls like with a fun aesthetic, awesome sound design, tough bosses, great environmental storytelling, and a very interesting method of progression. with the exception of a few traversal upgrades you have most of your abilities from the very start of the game but this information is slowly fed to you by the manual pages in a way that, again, feels intuitive!
Until you get to the final boss... the last few manual pages inform you in increasingly cryptic ways on how to get the good ending. You are encouraged to take notes on puzzle solutions and take a crack at deciphering the fake language just to get some semblance of how to progress.
You get neck deep in this manual rabbit hole and it honestly feels like a completely different game, and it sucks because I want to solve the puzzles as intended, using nothing but the manual and my intuition, like I've done for the rest of the game. But attempting to navigate this this Zelda 1 homage without outside help brings the end game to a screeching halt.
So if brain teasing cryptic puzzles really tickle your fancy then well, you have about 6 hours of a souls like to get through just to get to them.
This gear shift to what feels like an entirely different genre is what holds back Tunic from being a masterpiece in my eyes.
Overall I loved the experience, Just be prepare to whip out a guide for some of the later game puzzles.

134836591.review:
*I've completed the game offline, so actual playtime is probably around 20-25 hrs*

When I was a kid my best friend and I would spend our weekends playing Ocarina of Time together--not a two-player game of course, but we made it a cooperative effort because my friend had a knack for the action parts of the game and I had a knack for the puzzle parts of it. "Try playing that song there" or "toss a bomb on that spot" or "maybe come back as an kid/adult." The whole world of OoT was infused with this kind of mystery and significance that made it immersive and engaging. It all felt significant. And what I remember most about playing that game for the first time was my friend and I putting our heads together and the satisfaction of figuring out one of the many, many secrets for that game.

That's exactly how I feel about Tunic. 

It's beautiful to look at, to be sure, but the way the game plays with your perspective--secrets hiding behind corners, pathways that are clearly there but just hard to make out from your angle, chests just barely peaking out from behind a rock--it begins to change how you look at the world of the game. It all becomes potentially significant and often times, it is. 

And that's not even getting into some of the deeper secrets in this game. Without giving too much away, throughout the journey you pick up pages to the instruction booklet for the game. At first this seemed kind of silly to me, pages describing seemingly basic stuff; dodge rolling, stamina, blocking, and so on. But on closer inspection, almost every page has some hidden depth to it--a curious symbol that seems slightly out of place, a handwritten note in the margins, an arrow pointing to something off the map, or even a code for a free item. None of this is handed to you though, you have to pay attention, put pieces together, experiment,  and I found that all of it inspired a level of curiosity and intrigue I've rarely experienced in games. It begins to feel like no detail is superfluous, it's all very intentional, and it grabbed my attention for the whole game. 

Granted there are a few puzzles in this game that are so obscure as to be somewhere between absurd and genius. *Looking at you wind chimes and water reflecting on a cave wall* And lets just say that the last big puzzle in this game is a real doozy. Sorting that one out without the aid of Google should be something you can boast about on a college application.     

A brief nod to the combat: I'm an avid fan of the Dark Souls franchise. I've done multiple play-throughs of DS 1-3, Elden Ring, and Sekiro. That said, there are a few fights in this game that gave me a run for my money. So they're f-ing challenging. And just like solving one of the many subtle puzzles in the game, overcoming that challenge is very satisfying and rewarding. 

Finally, I love the music, May not be everyone's cup of tea, but I felt like it was the perfect feel for this game. It's one of the very few video game soundtracks I listen to just to listen to.

I dearly hope they make a sequel to this. I'd snatch it up in a heartbeat.

134711333.review:
Tunic is a masterpiece. 

If you like puzzles in any capacity, play it, you'll find something in it to love, if not all of it.

Tunic combines the fluid combat, ability unlocks, and exploration of any great Zelda-like with the added unlock of knowledge. Throughout the game, you will learn information that allows you to progress just as much as any hookshot would. 

Think Outer Wilds - a large portion of what holds you back is what you haven't yet learned about the game world. But there's the addition tons of unnecessary items, shortcuts, and other details that make every moment of your exploration through Tunic's beautiful world a joy that keeps you invested and coming back for more. While Outer Wilds took the view of "make everything matter" to keep you invested, Tunic tries instead to "make every moment a discovery." In most ways, it succeeds.

In my opinion, the one place Tunic fails is when you try to go for total completion of the game. In contrast to Outer Wilds, there are unimportant things, and you can look for those things after the game is over.  But because the motivating factor in Tunic is the consistent availability of secrets to uncover, it falls apart somewhat once you've found all but 2 or 3 things. 

If your stuck on a puzzle, even if you have everything you need, you might just end up trying the same things over and over, praying it'll work. And it gets frustrating, and takes away the wonder of this game. 

So if you play this game, which you most certainly should, complete it. Finish the game to the end. And let that be the end. 

Or, keep going - try to discover everything the game has to offer, - but don't be afraid to get hints from friends or the wonderful spoiler free secret guide you can find on Tunic's community page on Steam.

Whatever you chose to do, this is one of those games that will leave you wishing you could play it again, knowing it will never be the same. It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and one that will leave you feeling proud, lost, curious, and excited for the future of the art form that is video games.

Tunic is a hearty game in filled with brilliant puzzles and an amazingly charming world. 

Tunic is an open map adventure game of very few english words that has confidence in itself and it's players. Using natural human curiosity, learning through experience, and an in game manual that serves to nudge players in the right direction rather than spelling out your objectives, this game is a master class of making it's story your own.

The world itself is jammed full of interesting corners to poke your cute little fox nose into, finding new items, neat puzzles, and sometimes just plain fun little ester eggs to have some fun with. It puts the isometric view to good use, letting the world have a strong unique visual style while giving you a lot of elbow room to work with. 

The combat is pretty good. Most mooks are dispatched pretty easy but it's not hard to get ran down and killed. If the adventure part of the game is the legend of zelda for NES, then the combat is a FROM SOFTWARE game in no ambiguous terms. You have a set of healing potions that refill at checkpoints, those check points respawn all enemies, and you got a dodge roll with intangibility frames. It can be an uphill struggle to get use to the combat, especially if you're not use to enemies that are as relentless as these ones can be. 

There's little more I can say about the game without diminishing parts of the game. An adventure is best told from your own first person experience. Just know this game gets a full heart container from me. A truely amazing little masterpiece of a game.

134486022.review:
The notion of nostalgia is an interesting concept in creative media. The idea of generating appeal based not on the quality of your own work but for the emulation and or restoration of the quality of a different work. This becomes even stranger with the concept of anemoia: nostalgia for a time or a place one has never known. Which is what I felt playing Tunic.

Tunic draws much of its inspiration from earlier Legend of Zelda games such as ‘The Legend of Zelda’, ‘Zelda II, The adventure of link’ and ‘A link between worlds’. These were all games far beyond my time, by several decades even, yet I could still feel a connection and even a longing for such simpler games.

The name of the game for Tunic is simple: discovery. One of the most core aspects of the game is the process of rebuilding the game’s guidebook, allowing you to learn the context and function of many things you may have simply ignored or misunderstood. This results in the highest amount of “Oooooohhhhh thats how that works” situations of probably any game I’ve played.

Game play and direction is deliberately kept to a minimalist taste. combat abilities being three sword slashes and whatever items you have available. Puzzles are often a test of perspective or awareness rather than a say a riddle or contrived three part marathon. Most of the art assets could be recreated in programs like Blender relatively easily. Whilst the game could have come off as unchallenging or unimpressive, Tunic instead achieves a disciplined perfection of style. No hint misplaced, no encounter mistimed. It becomes down to the player to understand the situation as the pieces of the puzzle are commonly already in front of you.

Musically speaking Tunic steps lightly with more focus on ambience and leitmotifs to show continuation and similarity in areas that may not seem related, but later have their true natures revealed as time progresses. But the music does a type of heavy lifting often not mentioned in other reviews, and that is the what I like to call the Professor Layton factor: the music is simultaneously peaceful, distinctive but of a musical quality that it helps you think rather than distract. 

Overall, I hold high praises for this game, though there is one factor that is worth mentioning. Tunic is not a game for everyone. There are a number of puzzles that are annoyingly cryptic, requiring either a guide, a true sense of puzzle games or a frustratingly long amount of time to succeed with. And it's with this that I think it's not exclusionary to say that not everyone will be able to beat this game unassisted. 

And that's okay. 

To me, the most important part of Tunic is enjoying the game for what it is in your way. If that means completely unassisted to you then that's what you should do. But if you have more fun with a guide by your side then that's also valid. Tunic is a game that preaches the sharing of wisdom and understanding what others left behind, and I think that's a fine stance to take for both this game and all puzzle games.

Final score - 80/100

At the risk of sounding a bit like that awful copypasta, [i]to be fair[/i], you have to have a certain well-roundedness to be able to really appreciate TUNIC.  

Without going into actual detail (for this is one of those games which is best appreciated "going in blind"), the potential problem lies in that the game presents a challenge on two fronts which are not really synergistic at all: 
[list]
    [*]real-time, skill-based combat which is just a bit beyond the truly "casual" level, and
    [*]puzzles and secrets, hidden in plain sight and yet a fair bit more involved than a person disinterested in puzzles will have the inclination or patience to solve to completion.
[/list]

The result is that there is a very real chance that the game will fall flat for anyone not keen on both aspects; if you find this kind of combat daunting, then the game's action may wear you down before you get the chance to sink your teeth into the puzzles.  And If you are fine with the combat but aren't really tuned-in for the puzzles, you will eventually reach a point where the game appears to have reached a rather unsatisfying conclusion, while further progression, and the true endgame, are locked beyond an activity that holds little appeal to you.

No doubt the hope of the game's developers was that, for a certain kind of gamer, TUNIC would hit a sweet spot, becoming one of the best games of all time in the minds of its intended audience.  But, while I absolutely loved TUNIC, my honest feeling is that even the ideal TUNIC player will find the puzzle-solving side of the game to be [i]vastly[/i] more valuable than the combat.  The combat is fine, even enjoyable for the most part, but the puzzles and the general sense of intrigue that arises (again, I have to be frustratingly vague here) are exceptional.  I just don't see anything nearly as special about the action side of the game.

So, I would give this conditional recommendation: I wouldn't go into this for the combat alone.  But if you're not fazed by the combat, and you're interested in uncovering secrets and solving puzzles on a grand scale, this could be one of the most rewarding experiences in recent memory.

133311825.review:
This is a cute game that falls victim to bad map design and frustrating gameplay. 

Tunic is, in many ways, a competently made implementation of its genre. It's got a nice art style, and a few new neat ideas like being able to find manual pages. 

Unfortunately the actual experience of playing it is frequently turned into a frustrating slog primarily through poor map design. Tunic map is very, very complicated, largely in service of Tunic's favorite trick of showing you places you can't get to until later and hiding shortcuts behind geometry. That's not a bad thing in itself, but it does mean that you'll frequently find yourself very close as the crow flies to areas you've already cleared and want to get back to that are, through wrinkle of map layout, in fact a long and convoluted trek away.

A trek made more difficult by a guiding map that prioritizes aesthetics over actually showing you how to get where you want. In a simpler map design, not a problem, but with Tunic's map the lack of detail means it's often not clear how to get where you're going.

It's save points are also poorly laid out. Some are quite close together, but other new areas lock their save point behind multiple encounters of difficult enemies, and the closest outside save point is very far away. That means that to learn how to play around this difficulty spike, you'll need to spend around a full minute treking through already-cleared map to get back to the neat area every time you die. Which will happen a lot, especially for difficulty spikes like the quarry where there are sniper that one or two shot you. Each time something goes wrong, back to two areas away you go, to hike run through empty areas for 60 seconds.

It technically has a fast travel system, but it's laid out in such a way that it doesn't mitigate these problems.

It also has a lock-on 'focus' system that's fairly vital for combat sometimes, but is clunky to use. The default keybinds for switching focus targets require you to move your entire hand away from your attacks and items, and because it uses directional inputs instead of cycling through all available targets, it's hard to rebind, and difficult to get to focus on who you want.

There are lots of small problems like the interact prompt both taking a moment to show up and sharing a key with your dodge roll, meaning if you run up to a ladder and press interact, you'll lock yourself into a dodge animation for a second instead of grabbing the ladder. Not a huge problem, but they pile up.

I'm just going to keep listing them as I run into them. Was this game not QA tested or something?
- Some bosses can be pulled with the grapple hook, except when they're in some attacks, at which point instead of it failing *you* will be pulled to them and murderized
- The grappling hook can latch onto dead bodies in the seconds before they disappear, even if you're locked onto someone else. It locks you into the animation, doesn't do anything, and just got me killed.

Tunic has a lot going for it, as a mentioned before, but the omnipresent frustration of dealing with the map design sours the experience. I'm probably going to finish it once, and I don't regret putting time into it, but I'm not sure I'd recommend it to anyone that doesn't feel called to it.

More than anything, the setting and music made me wish I was playing Hyper Light Drifter instead, which exceeds Tunic in just about every category and doesn't have most of its flaws. Better combat, similar setting but more interesting, similar music but better, more engaging story, similar themes... I'd point anyone in that direction in a heartbeat.

Also, if you do play tunic you're going to want to customize the controls early on. The default control layout is pretty poorly optimized, feeling cramped and not using the mouse at all. The game doesn't tell you you can bind keys to the mouse, but you can, and I highly recommend putting your most-used few buttons on the mouse and rerouting the rest around your WASD keys.

EDIT: Now that I've finished the game, I can say with confidence that I don't recommend it. The second half of the game solves some of the map design problems (it turns out the entire map is designed to be super obtuse to navigate until you get a special dash when you're 75% finished), which is... a choice. But the omnipresent problems never really let up. 

Small places where you get stuck and have to reset, map design that remains obtuse even when you get the magic dash.

The boss design in particular is bad throughout the game. It's seldom clear when vulnerability windows are, what attacks are being telegraphed. The final boss is the worst example: its has a stunned state, but even after half an hour beating it I never figured out what triggered it. Not damage, not health loss, no clue. Some runs it got stunned three times, others none. 

It has several wildly different attacks that all share identical or near-identical windups, so the same telegraph sometimes is a short jab and sometimes is a two-part combo that will take your entire health pool if you don't get more out of the way. Those weren't the only radically different attack with an identical windup.

It seems to be able to cancel its own animations at random: attacks that usually have a two-second windup will sometimes come out instantly followed immediately by a second attack. These can even chain together, meaning at sometimes it will do a janky 6-attack flurry over the course of four or five seconds. As time went on I became less convinced this was intentional and not bad coding.

The effect is the same as with all the other bosses. I never once felt like I was learning a boss, growing familiar with its behaviors and beating it with finesse. You just run at it repeatedly until you get lucky and it chooses not to do its heavy attack six times in a row.

Overall, I just can't recommend it. Tunic has good points, certainly, but the actual experience of playing it is frustrating and tedious. The story is Hollow Knight to a T but less interesting, the everything is Hyper Light Drifter but worse. 

A solid attempt was made, but the finished product just doesn't measure up.

[b]"Tunic" is an adorable, indie, souls like game which, without being innovative at all, uses few fundamental gaming elements with so much care and perfection that it feels unique. Addictive battles with fluid animations and responsive controls are mixing magically with exploration and clever puzzle inside a colorful, eerie world full of mysteries and unexpected discoveries. "Tunic" shows how going back to the basics in a creative way can gives us gems.


Manometer: 8/10[/b]


The good
- Adorable aesthetics. Nice, minimalistic 3d graphics with vivid colors and atmospheric lighting. The cool day/night system gives it some variation too.
- Great world design with multiple height levels, hidden paths and alternative routes that get unlocked gradually as you play. Each region guides you masterfully in order to always be at the right path, but also not limit you from exploring the surroundings.
- Awesome core gameplay logic. The way that you unlock secrets and gain small pieces of knowledge through exploration and observation is amazing. Even after a lot of hours you keep discovering things that may related to basic control mechanics. The game is full of well hidden secrets and clever puzzles and always gives you enough hints so it never feels impossible or unfair. It even has its own real language that you can try to translate. So imaginative and well balanced.
- Fantastic animations. Soft bodies, particles, physics after each blow, everything seems smooth and natural. Protagonist's walking is so funny.
- Fast battles with nice controls and addictive kills. Everything feels fluid and responsive.
- It offers a decent variation of abilities, upgrades and tools that introduce new interesting mechanics when you acquire them, so the game never gets boring or repetitive.
- Well designed enemies. Each region has its own tribes. Bosses' design seems a little bit generic, but their battles are great and have really good pace.
- The story is cool but pretty abstract. The most interesting part though is trying to understand what's going on by collecting all these scattered pieces of information and putting them gradually together.
- All those illustrations at the pages you find are simply gorgeous. 

The bad
- It would be an entirely different game if you change this characteristic, but the fact that there are side invisible walls everywhere so you cannot jump down to the lower levels seemed to me odd and I could get used of it till the very end.
- Poor sound design with only few environmental sounds. The background music keeps playing almost always, which can be tiring after a while.
- Sometimes interacting with some objects like chests and stairs can be unresponsive.
- The story is pretty abstract and fragmented which isn't bad at all, but initially it doesn't give you enough clues to understand your purpose, what you are fighting for. So you play half of the game wandering and killing foes without knowing exactly why.

- great interconnected non-linear map design, whereby you unlock many shortcuts
- many secrets; the game is chalk full of secrets, which range in difficulty to find from mildly clever to needing a galaxy-brain
- stat levelling up
- difficult bosses whereby you have to learn their moveset and weaknesses; at least for me they were difficult
- an interesting, fallen, and mysterious world, whereby the narrative is the opposite of spoon-fed to you
- you ring two not-Bells-of-Awakening and collect the Hexforce and collect the not-Lord Souls

One of my biggest criticisms with the art direction is the fox protagonist has bead-eyes. He is still a cute fox, but he would've been far more cute and relatable if he had "normal" emotive eyes with an iris an such. Hopefully if the devs make another game, they'll mix up the eyes to be better. Otherwise, the lofi aesthetic is very cool, and the lofi soundtrack is amazingly good. The art in the manual is also great.

The game keeps you engaged by providing you interesting items and abilities as you progress. It also gets you to ask deep questions like:
- why tf am I praying to mecca
- why is my (incomplete) game manual scribbled over and slopped all over with coffee stains
- who is writing in pen on my manual
- in fact, why are parts of the map geography straight-up wrong
- why does it feel as if someone has been though so many places already before
- who made all these robots
- why and there so many meccas
- why does the purple stuff irradiate me like I'm at Chernobyl
- do I get to wield the cool sword
So yea that is all cool.

The last 1/4 of the game sucks cuz:
- it takes away all of your upgrades, but makes you play a long and difficult section whereby the game mechanics are pretty much the same. I don't think this was necessary from a story or gameplay point of view. They could've just made this section hard without taking away your upgrades, and thus not removing your feeling of progression. This choice would be like if Dark Souls yeeted your levels and weapon upgrades partway through until you defeated a couple of Lord Soul bosses.
- to not get what I regard as a bad unsatisfying ending, you need to get a bunch of difficult collectables. Getting these collectables requires you to press your d-pad/arrow-keys a lot, with no indication if you made a mistake. I think the default ending is too unsatisfying given the amount of manual-decoding, careful exploring, and d-pad effort needed to get the okay ending. For most of the "golden path" stuff, I used online guides.

This game is a great demonstration on why games don't come with manuals anymore. They've been rid-of for good reason. Having to decode and rely on a game manual for important gameplay purposes is an immersion-breaking anti-feature. Games whereby you must solve their secrets and challenges by immersing yourself in the game world are far more compelling.

Anyways, if you don't think the last 1/4 of the game will bother you, go for buying it.

This review is spoiler-free. TUNIC is a game like no other, and I'd recommend everyone to pick it up and give it a chance. But before going more into detail, you should know that this is a [b]knowledge based[/b] game, looking for guides or tutorials WILL take away from the experience.

TUNIC is all about the feeling of finding secrets, discovering things you didn't know of and that were possible, like mastering a fighting game by using secret movesets. It's a kind of language that you will learn to pick up, but it takes a while to get there, so be a bit patient and enjoy the other aspects of the game.

It is true that the game [i]is hard[/i] and that it uses the Dark Souls principle of dying and trying until you get it right. It can be quite challenging in both difficulty and progression, but it is accessible enough for you to only focus on the things that you want to do, don't be ashamed to reduce the difficulty if it's too much, just enjoy the game at your own pace.

Exploration and problem solving is very Zelda-like, as in the first and original The Legend of Zelda. You are just thrown into the world, no objective, no cutscenes, no preludes, just you and the world that TUNIC offers. Most of the hints and guidance you will receive come from an special in-game item, and believe me, it really is your best and only ally.

To fully enjoy this game you need to be willing to get completely lost, you must accept that there will be times where you have absolutely [i]no idea[/i] of where to go next or how to make progress. These are the [b]main[/b] puzzles of TUNIC, finding the way forward.

The music in this game is amazing, it never gets repetitive and really helps a lot to define the style of the game. It may not be very orchestral or incredibly iconic like other games, but there's definitely a lot of tracks that stand out! Lifeformed and Janice Kwan really put something very special, and you can [i]feel it[/i].

I do admit it, there are times were some secrets are just a slap in the face, but must of the puzzles and secrets felt right and natural to solve. There are a couple of bugs here and there, but none of them are to the detrement of the game.

132698162.review:
The marketing and reviews for this game are intentionally vague, because it's one of those "everything is a spoiler!" exploration games. That's not entirely true, while obviously gameplay mechanics are best kept a secret to keep learning them fun, there are some things worth knowing before you purchase this game.
- It is indeed similar to FEZ, but with much, much greater focus on combat - and combat here is INSANELY difficult, unforgiving, brutal and often simply unfair. If you have the patience, reflexes and habits of a soulslike veteran, you may enjoy it... but otherwise expect all the frequent enemy engagements to feel incredibly frustrating. You never truly lose your progress, but do expect to get stuck for hours in the same place because you can't quite land a sequence of 100 dodges in a row.
- HOWEVER, the game has a built-in god-mode you can enable in options menu for complete invulnerability. And I thank the developers for including it, because there's more to this game than just the tricky combat, and I would not be able to enjoy it otherwise.
- Almost all text in the game uses a complex made-up (but well-designed and coherent) writing system, and the game does not teach the player how to read it! You DO NOT need to comprehend it to 100% the game, but if you also want to understand the entire lore, all NPCs and instructions, then you'll have to find your Rosetta stone and decipher the texts on your own - and it is not just a simple cipher. Up to you whether that sounds appealing.
- There isn't much of a story in the game. Yes, it is thematic, and there is a bit of lore you get to learn and explore, but expect zero interactions with characters, or evolving plot. The world just.... is there. Don't expect any narrative to that cute fox's adventures.
- While the game does offer a lot of fun meta-puzzles, they don't exactly scratch that The Witness itch as some of the marketing tries to promise; your progress isn't ever blocked by your lack of understanding, but simply lack of information.
- But more often than not, your progress will be blocked by your combat skills. You will often think "these enemies are far too strong, maybe I'm supposed to complete a different route first?". To which the game responds with a firm "nope, git gud".

132150965.review:
So, what gets many people (and me) hyped about Tunic is that it feels a lot like being a little kid playing one of these old school games on the NES, SNES or Game Boy (especially the 2D Zelda games). You could barely read and understand what was even going on, but had a blast anyways. If you were living in Europe there is a good chance the game wasn't even localized properly, so most of the text went right over your head. Everything was super mysterious, adventurous and playing the game felt super challenging at the time. Maybe one of your friends had one of these player guides, which gave your smooth brain a chance to actually progress through the game.

Tunic captures these early gaming experiences very well and transfers them brilliantly to modern times where games got a lot better while you got a lot older and more experienced playing them. There is a strong focus on self-guided exploration and discovery while the game takes a more modern approach trying to nudge you slightly in the right directions.

However, this is another one of these games, where going in knowing as little as possible is definitely recommended. A sizable portion of progression is gated through knowledge of the game and the world, which means that your first playthrough can definitely be tainted if you know all too much before playing.

That makes it of course harder for you to decide if you would enjoy the game or not. I was on the fence for a long time, especially because I read so many reviews comparing the combat to Dark Souls or Bloodborne. I am not a big fan of these games but I am glad I took the risk with Tunic. While the Souls games might have been the inspiration for some of the combat mechanics, I really don't think the difficulty comes even close. I will not deny that some of the bosses can be challenging, but I feel you have a lot of room to outsmart combat encounters if you use all the tools at your disposal.

So if you are keen to explore an expansive Zelda-like world, riddled with treasure and intricate puzzles, and want to experience a little throwback to the good old gaming times, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to you. And if it is important to you: Yes, there is replay value :-).
