Easily the best indie game of 2022, if not the best indie I've ever played. I genuinely regret not playing it soon enough to vote for it during the Steam Awards and Game Awards.

Avoiding spoilers as much as I can:
I went into this game expecting a Link's Awakening knock off and came out with one of the most unique, revolutionary, constantly mind-blowing experiences I've ever had. I found the design choices to be interesting from the beginning of the game (like how the presented language is mainly consisted of its own fantasy language with enough English to comprehend the message). However, as the game progressed, the amount of revelations I had to come to using my own ability was insane. I've never experienced a game that has had so many creative layers of secret design that was also very intuitively placed throughout. Completing this game entirely without a guide is one of the most rewarding experiences I've ever felt. I absolutely recommend this game to anyone and everyone who is willing to go deeper than what shows on the surface.

131710655.review:
Tunic looks and feels simple but is actually very complex beneath the surface. It intentionally conceals much and expects you to figure things out on your own. Being given info gradually in the form of pages from a guide book is something I've never seen done before, and its meta appearance complete with hand-written notes was a very novel idea. But that's just scratching the surface of the intricacies this game has to offer.  

Despite its apparent action/adventure appeal Tunic's combat - while generally polished - isn't particularly impressive. You use the same basic sword through the course of the game and the sub-weapons don't contribute a whole lot to the experience. Indeed, Tunic is at its core a puzzle game - the majority of which are well-designed and require a good deal of spacial awareness and attention to detail to solve. I'd argue that some are actually a bit [i]too[/i] obscure, but even looking up the solutions to a few was satisfying given how creative they are.

As incredible as it is that the glyphs you see throughout the game make up a unique script that can apparently be translated, for the average player this makes the guide book mostly indecipherable apart from a few English keywords. I don't think it was a good decision to leave so much story-building content inaccessible to those who don't look it up online. It also makes for a frustrating lack of clarity when trying to figure out the locations of some objectives. I was looking forward to being given some sort of translation tool eventually and was disappointed when it never arrived. 

While straying into the arcane at times Tunic offers impressively challenging puzzles and imparts info to its players in cleverly sneaky ways. While the combat is a bit unremarkable in contrast, it's still fun as an adventure game with some challenging encounters as well.

Tunic is perhaps the most memorable singleplayer game I've ever played. Come for the top-down action blending Zelda games and Dark Souls, stay for the amazing scene-setting and puzzles.

As you may have heard, part of this game's challenge is the fact that the manual is presented [i]within the game itself[/i] and is rendered mostly in a fictional language. This is a major part of what gives the game its unique flair, but it also means that this is a game that requires some measure of patience. In addition to being the most memorable singleplayer game I've completed, Tunic is also the one that had me staring blankly at my ceiling for the longest time. On dozens of occasions I was very, very tempted to just look up solutions to puzzles or guides on what to do next after running in circles -- and in the end I eventually did look at a couple hints just to make sure I wasn't gaslighting myself on a couple of the more elaborate puzzles.

If you have the patience to handle the arcane process of learning a game without having any guides, Tunic is sure to be a treat for you. I've never played a game that gave me such a visceral feeling of solving a mystery before.

131354062.review:
Tunic is the game I wish I made. When I was a kid playing Ocarina of Time on the Nintendo 64 at my best friend's place, we would always talk about making our own game. It was going to be called Ravie the Raccoon, and would basically be a Zelda inspired adventure game where you play as a racoon. I've thought about this game a lot since them, and had even considered (naively) trying to make something like it after teaching myself a bit of programming and 3D modelling. Tunic is exactly the game we wanted to make, but way better than we could have done ourselves. I'm glad Tunic exists so I can confidently put my game making fantasy to bed.

Tunic is clearly a passion project made with a lot of love. While it has a wonderful nostalgic feel to it for anyone who grew up with N64 and earlier consoles, it also adopts many more modern game mechanics to keep it from being just a rehash of games we've seen before. The game is difficult, but fair, making you have to learn all the mechanics of combat to get through it; button mashing won't do. The combat is very satisfying once you get the hang of it.

One of the best elements of the game is it's secrets. It doesn't hand hold, or really explain anything at all until you uncover the strategically placed instruction manual pages. This is one of the most clever elements I've seen in a game in a long time. I recommend most people to try as hard as they can to not look up answers, as discovering it on your own is half the fun. Playing with someone else to work through the puzzles is a great experience too; just don't go to someone who's finished the game and ask them to tell you everything. You can only play it for the first time once, so try to make it on your own as long as you can. I'll admit having needed to look some things up for very late game parts, and if I hadn't played with someone else, I'd probably have gotten stuck earlier, but most of the spots just need a bit of time and thought to get through.

Overall, this is one of my favorite games ever, and I think it will be a classic in gaming for years to come. Great work Andrew!

131089519.review:
Man, after being starved of oldschool 2D Zelda-like games for so long, it feels great to play Tunic. An absolute masterclass in world design. The game is full of those classic "oooooh" moments, when you realize how interconnected the world is - even with paths that don't even need to get unlocked but are just well hidden from one side and obvious from the other (looking at you Quarry entrance). Tunic manages to deeply immerse you in its world, while absolutely every aspect of the gameplay gets integrated in the lore - even the freaking manual. Most impressive about Tunic how the game manages to implement all kinds of  puzzles into every aspect of its gameplay, I don't want to spoil anything, so, I just recommend you look into the manual pages you find and try to tinker some stuff out by yourself before looking into guides. The less you know the better. 

In short, decent combat, great world design(!), awesome puzzles, superb lore, and probably the best manual I have ever seen in a video game. Tunic is worth its full price. Easily one of the best games of 2022.

PS: If you enjoyed Tunic, chances are you'll also like Death's Door. It has less emphasis on puzzles and is a bit more combat heavy, but the world & sound design is equally great. So glad these two came out back to back, hopefully 2023 continues this trend.

131088705.review:
Spoiler-free Review:

Zelda meets Dark souls is the most common description for this game which I agree with. But I would mention that it would be early Zelda, not BOTW era. 

The game is by far the hardest game I've ever played, and can be very frustrating but it is only as hard as you make it.

The game doesn't hold your hand at all, it doesn't even tell you the controls when you begin. 

As you play the game you collect pages for a game manual that explains functions of the game, the harder the page is to find the more important is the information you would read in it.  So the early easy to find pages would be things like basic attack controls, the meaning of common items etc.

Your best friend is experimentation, you will have to test items/consumables to figure out what they do. Combining buttons of two different weapons might give you a new ability, so you get rewarded for trying as much as you can in the game.

So there will be times where you die over and over to a boss (or regular enemies), you don't know where to go or what your next objective is. You get the urge to just give up or Google it but instead you decide to explore and you find a hidden passage behind some bushes with a page where it tells you some vital information you had no clue of! You feel very rewarded for having been a thorough explorer. 

In fact I haven't played a game before that makes you feel this rewarded for paying attention. I was dying a lot early to mid game because I was missing a page explaining an important detail to your character and once I found it everything made more sense.

These are the things that make this game unique, the enemy system with health and bosses is your typical Zelda-esque game and quite self explanatory if you ever played them so I won't go into any details there. But I would put the difficulty on the same level as Dark souls games and not quite as easy as Zelda.

You need to outsmart the bosses, learn their attack patterns, figure out their weaknesses. The manual will once again help you with this.

You can explore most of the world in any order, maps are also part of the manual so if you decide to go to a distant land early you will be in for a rough time. No map, and high level enemies, good luck... But maybe you find some important item or pages there to help you elsewhere. Worth a shot but get used to dying!

Good luck on the journey! Have patience, and take breaks when you feel frustrated! It will be worth it.

130952471.review:
HOWWWW has this game not totally blown up!? It's impossible to describe what makes it great without bumping into spoilers, so I'll try to tip-toe around a lot of the game if you'll pardon my vagueness:
Tunic obviously borrows a lot of imagery from the original Zelda; in many ways it's a modern take. The goal of the original Zelda was to get you invested in exploring the world, uncovering secrets, and fighting powerful enemies. Where the original Zelda succeeded for its year, just graphically overhauling it and putting it in front of a modern gaming audience wouldn't necessarily capture that sense of exploration... Tunic (in my opinion) succeeds with absolute style in making you want to figure out its world.
This game has souls-like combat that's fairly difficult, but barely punishes you for dying (fight 1-5 basic enemies and the penalty is reversed) AND offers a variety of difficulty mods in case you're more interested in just the puzzles. Meanwhile if you're more interested in just the combat you can just use a guide for the puzzles. I think the game would be fun enough with either the puzzle-box world or the souls-like combat alone. 
It's on the shorter end; at time of writing I have 35 hours but have gone through a new game plus and I didn't use the internet to solve any of the puzzles, but I don't think it's something you'll binge through in one session on your first playthrough... The beauty of the game is in the things you learn on that first playthrough that make smashing through it on subsequent playthroughs so satisfying - not just because you got better at combat and know exactly where to go, but because the way you traverse the world - even on a fresh save - will change dramatically as you master the game's secrets.
Seriously, you'll walk the same path several times and each time you'll learn something unique about it despite that it doesn't seem like anything strange could possible be going on - it evokes that sense of mastering something.
Because knowledge is power in this game, I recommend not watching a playthrough or any significant content beforehand... There's a good chance you'll spoil one of several things that aren't just story-related, this is one of the few games where mechanical spoilers are the most impactful kind. 
If you loved a link to the past and dark souls with their complex inter-connected worlds, you absolutely HAVE to give Tunic a go. There's so much more I want to praise, but again, it's so hard to praise the game without spoiling what makes it great, so I guess I'll leave this here rather than dance in circles. 
Seriously, gaem is gewd. Pla gaem.

The parry system is terrible... you can't parry on reaction, you have to parry via memorisation. Due to the startup frames of the parry taking so long, a tiny hitbox window,  and recovery frames that seem to last an eternity, parrying often feels like fighting in a vat of molasses. I wouldn't gripe about this so much if the mechanic itself wasn't crucial to success in almost every boss fight. Furthermore, i-frames on the dodge roll seem spotty at best... your hitbox extends forward as the roll begins, which makes for a sloppy animation that's hard to pull off. 

Aside from that, the game is fun... I guess? The map is kind of annoying... I did appreciate the "user manual" that needs to be decoded as you play, but I kinda got sick of flipping through it after awhile. 

There's an upgrade system... but it's pointless at best, since the discovery of said upgrades are strictly linear - and there's no room for customisation... which begs the question, why have them at all? 

A lot of enemies use cheap tactics, and it doesn't take much to get overwhelmed. More often than not I had more success by cheesing these scenarios, rather than trying to pull of interesting parries (see above). 

All in all I think Tunic is a bit over hyped.... I get it... people love Zelda.... but geez. Many of the themes, art styles, and mechanics are too "on-the-nose" for me. This game doesn't feel like it has an original bone in its body. 

Also, the story is butt.

130776015.review: Tunic is a very fun game. It's one of those that's easy to get sucked into, making you lose track of time as you explore deeper and further. The game has plenty of surprises and mechanics to keep the player invested. Visually, it's beautiful, and they've done an excellent job setting up a post-apocalyptic world torn between nature and machine. This game is obviously very inspired, taking the best ideas from other successful games. While playing this, I often feel reminded of Legend of Zelda, Hyper Light Drifter, Metroid, Dark Souls, and even Monument Valley. I do however have a few problems with the game that stops it from being my "Game of the Year"... It just feels sorta clunky in certain areas. The combat doesn't feel as smooth as it could, because attacks/dodges/magic abilities don't chain into each other very well. I personally hate that I can't sprint without first rolling. You don't have a lot of control over your focus, and trying to toggle it to the desired target can often be a very undermining hassle in the middle of combat. Some of the exploration can be more frustrating than rewarding at times, so patience is very necessary for this game. Honestly though, my biggest personal issue with the game, and of course it's just my opinion: the lack of fast travel. The lack of fast travel in this game has already made for some of the longest and most tedious treks in my gaming career, and I've played all the soulsborne games. I'm only 6 hours into this game. Just turn those little checkpoint things into fast travel locations! To me, that would take this game from a 9 to a 10. I hope the devs see this and know that they really did make something really awesome and special, and I hope my feedback can be of good use :)

Tunic is the embodiment of don't judge a book by its cover. When I first saw a trailer for it, I thought it was a cutesy Zelda style adventure action game. But after it released, I heard there was more underneath the cover and I was intrigued enough to pick it up. My playthrough of Tunic reminded me of when I was a kid playing the original NES Zelda. There was no internet back then. You had to figure out things on your own and through word of mouth. The backstory of Zelda was told through the manual. It also had information on how to play, items, enemies, and a map you could reference. 

In Tunic, you also collect pages of an in-game manual. The major difference is Tunic's manual is mostly in its own language with some english sprinkled in there for important information. This reminded me of what Dark Soul's creator Hidetaka Miyazaki said about how growing up he would often read books he couldn't understand and would have to piece together the meaning. It is pretty clear the Souls games also had some inspiration on the gameplay in Tunic as well.

Most of the game plays like you would expect, but near the end there is much more focus on puzzle solving than combat. This didn't bother me much as I love puzzles and the final puzzle of the game was one of the most challenging and satisfying to solve in any game. That said, I would have expected there to be more challenging adversaries near the end game, especially after spending most of the latter quarter of the game powering up.

After I finished the game, I discovered there were even more secrets in the game I was unaware of. I won't spoil them here, but it is reminiscent of games like Fez and The Witness. It is clear that the devs put a lot of love into the game and embodied that spirit of putting in content that only the most dedicated players will discover it and I just think that's neat.

After gaining all achievements, I can say that I really liked this game, to the point that I think it's one of the best games "for me" that I've played in recent years. I found game design elements in it that I already enjoyed in FEZ and The Witness, but handled even better here.

All the environmental puzzles and discovery aspects I found extremely satisfying, but there are a couple of points I'd like to address.

Of the 36 achievements I managed to get 32 by myself and without any guidance or solution. This to me is extraordinary, since the game has many "metatextual/environmental puzzles" that in other games are generally done in a worse way or that depend more on moon logic. Things that in other games would have me searching on google in no time, here kept me in-game. Tunic is exceptional in giving you "everything you need".

Of the other 4 achievements, instead:
- One took me almost 3 "empty" hours because I knew "where it was", but a very stupid detail and a red herring (cryptic reference to understand which one I'm referring to: alarmed birds) distracted me.
- I found one too "demanding", in the sense that it is the only one that requires understanding of the language that Tunic uses. I reached half of what was needed, but for the last part I looked online for the translation (cryptic reference to understand which one I'm referring to: wet letters).
- One I found just free hate on the player. It's something that is extremely missable in the first playthrough, and asked me for an ad-hoc new game just to do it (cryptic reference to understand which one I mean: pew pew).
- One is feasible as long as you play "conservative" (cryptic reference to understand which one I'm referring to: piggy bank). The problem I have with this achievement is that I already play conservative in these games by default, but the game at one point pushes you not to, to the point that another achievement is achieved by partially "letting go". It pissed me off that I had to recover it in the ad-hoc run for the previous achievement since I was "almost there" in the main run but reached a point where it wasn't achievable anymore.

These last two achievements go so much against what (in my opinion) is the spirit of Tunic, that it would have been a better game without them.

Apart from these small negative points imho, as I said above this has been an amazing experience. 130490390.review:
I really liked the game. I put off playing it for a while because some of the negative reviews pointing to the punishing combat put me off, but I'm glad I played it anyway! Here are my thoughts on parts of the game.

Combat: It's fine, completely serviceable, but nothing exciting. Your move-set is extremely simple, consisting of a very basic 3-hit sword swing combo, a shield, and a few extra goodies you can use (bombs, projectiles, etc). Basically, imagine how combat works in a 2D Zelda game, and that makes up about 90% of how combat works. The remaining 10% is souls-like. You have rolling for i-frames, stamina that depletes when you roll or defend (but NOT attack, you can always attack). And you have some bog-standard "flasks" you can use to heal up during or between fights. Overall, I thought it felt good, just nothing special.

Difficulty wise, it's a bit tricky. As you progress, you will find areas where enemies can do a LOT of damage to you. You will die in 1-2 hits to some of these guys. And sometimes those enemies will not take much damage from you either. It can be frustrating, but there is a big upside. Every enemy in the game has very simple attack patterns and behavior. It is surprisingly easy to learn how to take on every combat challenge in the game. In other words, the game does not demand much from you mechanically. Once you learn an enemy's attacks it isn't that hard to dodge or shield them. The toughest fights in the game for me didn't take me more than 10 tries. Best of all, if you're really having trouble somewhere, the magic items and consumables available to you are very strong. In short, if you're having a lot of difficulty somewhere, maybe you're just not using the right strategy for the situation.

Exploration/discovery: The game shines here. You are never explicitly told what to do, it is up to you to figure out what the next step is. But the direction you should go is not esoteric. The game gives plenty of hints on what you can do, and what you should do, and it drops those hints in a natural way at the appropriate times. There are also plenty of secrets to discover, and it feels really good to find them.

Speaking of discovery, I'll cover the puzzle part here too. The puzzles in Tunic aren't actually that difficult, in the calculation sense. They're difficult in the discovery sense. You see, in Tunic, the puzzles are actually testing your knowledge and observation. Sometimes you'll see something that feels out of place. Sometimes you'll see something that seems weirdly organized. Sometimes you'll notice a pattern. And the game is asking you: do you know what's going on here? Can you connect the dots? And I like that a lot.

130438726.review:
TUNIC's blend of Souls-like combat, FEZ-like puzzles, Zelda-like overworld, and beautiful art style, music and sound design has quickly catapulted it into becoming [b]one of my favorite games of all time[/b].

From a semi-forced isometric world view, you play as a young fox cub as they stumble around in a world that has fallen from grace, and left worse for wear. What strikes you first time you play it is that the text on signs, the HUD and even the in-game manual is written in a mysterious, indecipherable alphabet, and you have to rely on your own instincts, logical reasoning and curiosity to figure out what most of the things mean. 

The game does no hand holding. It throws you into the world and goes "You're on your own now!" And that is something you don't see much these days. There's a lot of hand holding in modern games, and TUNIC bucks that trend, which is something I appreciate very much. The game trusts the player to be smart, attentive and inquisitive, and explore every nook and cranny of the world to find all the things hidden just around the corner, out of sight.

Depending on how quickly you pick up on the things the game gives you, the [b]playtime[/b] to complete the game can take anywhere between 10 and 30 hours. There's also the case of getting a [i]true[/i] ending, which takes up the majority of the time in the second half of the game. And that extra time is well spent for getting the true ending, I will go ahead and say that much.

In terms of [b]performance[/b], it runs excellent on both my PC AND my Steam Deck. Crisp 60 FPS on my Deck with zero dips in framerate and plenty of battery life.

So yeah, an absolutely rock solid recommendation from me.

(**Spoiler free review**) I have mixed feelings on this game. The first portion of the game all the way up to the final boss absolutely captivated me. The combination of exploration, combat, and puzzle solving is satisfying and well-balanced, and the art style and music are incredible.

But then I reached the point at which it turns from an adventure game into a straight-up puzzle game. Don't get me wrong, the puzzles are well-designed and fun, but there's a lot of them and they are quite obscure and difficult. After solving the first few, I found this portion of the game became very tedious without any of the great pacing from before. It honestly felt like a bait and switch, as though the developers brought me in with 15 hours of incredible combat, world-building, and exploring, and then decided to abruptly jettison everything except the puzzles.

130395205.review:
Fantastic game, possibly my favorite release of 2022.  I've already 100% completed it, and it left me wanting more.

As some reviews have pointed out, the combat is indeed incredibly difficult, though there are options to mitigate this.  That said, with the exception of one or two things, it never quite feels 'unfair'.  The 'Souls-like' tag is well earned - you will die (probably not quite as often as in an actual Dark Souls game) but rarely does it feel like you didn't get punished for an avoidable mistake.

MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD

[spoiler]That said, I do somewhat dislike the endgame tactic games tend to use where your stats get reset, then have to deal with enemies that would be a pain regardless.  Enemies whose attacks lower your max HP is an interesting idea for the last act of a game...but when you also have beginning level stats, you're kind of screwed.  Thankfully, you do get to keep your items, and they do help immensely (at least, until New Game +).  To its credit, TUNIC handles the blending of these two annoying mechanics with relative grace, and it doesn't feel like an impossible challenge, but blending ****, dirt, and ice cream with grace still leave you with a **** shake.  It also led to the only times I died in this game and felt frustrated instead of challenged, with one exception - the damn double library statues, but given that I could do those last [i]greatly[/i] mitigated that annoyance.  The Combat Gauntlet was also a little much, but that ties into the whole 'reset stats for the last act' bit, and since there was a save point right before, and it was not so bad with a little practice, I'm calling that one a wash.[/spoiler]

But those are relatively minor squabbles.  What was more important to me was the realization I had about an hour into the game, after the first boss - something [i]magical[/i] was happening.  I was enjoying this game in a way I hadn't enjoyed a game in years, maybe decades.  The exploration, the puzzle solving, the discovery of mechanics that had always been there - TUNIC is a game that would feel right at home with a release 20-30 years ago.  A well-put together game that has you discovering the world organically as you play, finding secrets that are just there for fun, finding paths that were ALWAYS there but only became obvious after the first time around.  I think the collection of the manual pages exemplifies this the best - the pages contain maps for areas, details of the game mechanics, controls, and so on.  On multiple occasions, I would collect a page, look at it, and figure out how I was supposed to interact with those odd doors, or those golden pads, or the weird black obelisks, or how to run, or how to upgrade stats, or what enemies I would be facing in the next area, or any number of things that made collecting the pages fun and exciting in a way that hasn't been done well in a long time.

One more added note: the devs truly understand the gaming community.  I saw a sort of pseudo-interview they did during a speedrun where they were commenting on what tricks they were and weren't aware of, and many of the tricks were listed under the 'yeah, we knew about this' list.  Being able to freeze enemies and use them as grapple points to get around barriers?  Yup, the team knew about that, and decided to leave it in but only for enemies that weren't flying enemies.  Sequence breaking?  Are you kidding, the game is designed specifically to allow it!  There's even an achievement for getting a specific late-game item before the sword.  Cheesing the boss for an easy kill?  Go ahead, which method did you use?

By far, my biggest gripe is that the game wasn't longer.

TUNIC isn't a perfect game...but it's damn close.  9.75/10 - a must buy.  I greatly look forward to a sequel, or anything else from the devs.
